{{Infobox artist | honorific_prefix = | name = Adeline Palmier Wagoner | honorific_suffix = | image = Adeline_Palmier_Wagoner,_Kajiwara_Photo.jpg | image_upright = | alt = | caption = from ''Notable Women of St. Louis'', 1914 | birth_name = Adeline Palmier Myers | birth_date = {{birth date|1868|02|14}} | birth_place = St. Louis, Missouri | death_date = {{death date and age|1929|04|21|1868|02|14}} | death_place = | resting_place = | resting_place_coordinates = | nationality = | residence = | education = | alma_mater = | known_for = President of the St. Louis branch of the National Plant, Flower and Fruit Guild | notable_works = | style = | movement = | spouse = Harry Epply Wagoner | awards = | elected = | patrons = | memorials = | website = | module = }} '''Adeline Palmier Wagoner''' (February 14, 1868 – April 21, 1929) was an American volunteer organizational leader and author. She served as president of the [[St. Louis]], Missouri, branch of the National Plant, Flower and Fruit Guild, a charity for the poor and afflicted, and as president of the Shakespeare Tercentenary Society.
==Early life== Adeline Palmier Myers was born on February 1, 1868, in [[St. Louis|St. Louis, Missouri]].<ref>{{cite web|url=https://familysearch.org/ark:/61903/3:1:33S7-95Q5-9S8C?cc=1923888|title=Family Search|accessdate=5 August 2017}}</ref> She was the daughter of Frederick Myers and Louisa Palmier (b. 1837). Myers's mother wrote the words for ''Let Us Sing of Old Missouri'', music by Johanna Mohr, arranged by Esther M. Harkins.<ref>{{cite book|title=Catalog of Copyright Entries: Musical compositions, Part 3, Volume 10, Issue 1|date=1915|publisher=U.S. Government Printing Office|page=366|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=gjXQAAAAMAAJ|accessdate=5 August 2017}}</ref>
Myers had one sister who married Walter Dray, of [[Chicago]]. Wagoner's mother was the daughter of Michel Beaulier Palmier (1800–1851), granddaughter of Jean Beaulieu (dit Palmier), a captain of the [[War of 1812]], and great-granddaughter of Michel Joseph Beaulieu, captain of the first regularly organized militia of Illinois, and Angelique Chauvin, daughter of a French officer of [[Fort de Chartres]], Illinois.<ref>{{cite journal|title=Daughters of the American Revolution|journal=Lineage Book|date=1927|volume=97|page=106|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=wZEBAAAAMAAJ|accessdate=5 August 2017|author1=Revolution|first1=Daughters of the American}}</ref>
Myers graduated from the Central High School and the Normal High School. She was elected class historian, representative, and wrote and delivered the class poem.<ref name="Johnson" /> As a young girl, she was a prominent member of the McCullagh Dramatic Club, of which Gen. [[William Tecumseh Sherman]] was president, and [[Wayman C. McCreery]], secretary. Myers played the principal parts with [[Augustus Thomas]], William Beaumont Smith, Guy Lindsley, and others who laters became professionals in the theater world. She took the leading part in one of Thomas' first plays, ''The Cattle King''.<ref name="Johnson" /> She also assisted in raising money for the [[YWCA|Young Women's Christian Association]], as well as taken part in carnivals given for the benefit of hospitals, asylums, etc.<ref name="Johnson" />
==Career== Adeline Wagoner was the vice-president and recording secretary of the Chapter 0 of the [[P.E.O. Sisterhood]], founded on January 21, 1869,<ref>{{cite book|last=Clapp|first=Stella|title=Out Of The Heart: A Century of P.E.O. 1869–1969|publisher=The P.E.O. Sisterhood|page=1}}</ref> as a seven-member sorority at Iowa Wesleyan College in Mount Pleasant, Iowa. It was the second sorority to be founded in the U.S.<ref name="wolf-wendel">{{cite book |last=Wolf-Wendel |first=Lisa |author2=Sheila Pedigo |editor=Barbara K. Townsend |title=Two-Year Colleges for Women and Minorities |year=1999 |publisher=[[Routledge]] |isbn=0-8153-3173-8 |pages=57 |chapter=Two-Year Women's Colleges }}</ref>
In St. Louis, Wagoner was the president of The National Plant, Flower and Fruit Guild, whose motto was "When we can and what we can". The members of the guild headed by Wagoner asked for donation of fruit, flowers, magazines, delicacies for the table, clothing, etc. These articles were then distributed regularly, and particularly on anniversaries and holidays.<ref name="Johnson" />
In 1913 the guild distributed 21,000 bunches of flowers, 36 bushels of fruit, 16 gallons of strawberries, 500 glasses of jelly, hundreds of magazines, 200 potted plants, and different articles of clothing, such as shawls, stockings, and handkerchiefs, Christmas boxes and bags by the hundreds, and a great quantity of tobacco. In the summer of 1913 they distributed seeds to children to plant back-yard gardens, open-lot gardens, and window boxes. Eight prizes were awarded to the best arranged window boxes.<ref name="Johnson" />
Florence Putnam was in charge of the Flowers department. Some of the other women who were most active in assisting Wagoner, and who hold the important offices in the local organization, were Mrs. Frederick Kreismann, Mrs. James McCourtney, Mrs. H.H. Wagoner ([[Sophronia Wilson Wagoner]]), Mrs. H.H. Evans, Mrs. U.L. Clark, Mrs. William Huppert, Mrs. Relle Forse, Mrs. Hugh Romanoski, Mrs. A.A. Flanders, Mrs. E.J. Kramer and Mrs. J. Rossman.<ref name="Johnson" />
The Guild did also volunteering work at the Poor House, later City Infirmary or [[St. Mary's Infirmary]] (currently a [[National Register of Historic Places listings in Downtown and Downtown West St. Louis|NRHP place]] in Downtown St. Louis): they brought tobacco, pencils, pads of paper, shoe strings, knives, etc., for the men; in the woman's department they put potted plants by each bed, and a little basket of sewing materials with a box of cake, candy and fruit, also quilt pieces and little ornaments for the hair and dress; for the consumptive ward, where the most critical patients were kept, they brough sunshine and angel cakes; vegetable plants for the gardens were donated by the City Workhouse gardens.<ref name="Johnson" />
Wagoner was the president of the Shakespeare Tercentenary Society, based at the Planters Hotel.<ref>{{cite book|title=The Register of women's clubs|date=1924|page=112|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=634fAQAAIAAJ|accessdate=5 August 2017}}</ref> The honorary president was Dr. Denton J. Snider, a Shakespeare scholar.<ref>{{cite journal|title=Missouri School Journal|journal=Missouri School Journal|date=1922|volume=39|page=160|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=wGQ0AQAAMAAJ|accessdate=5 August 2017}}</ref> Originally a study club, dedicated to a consideration of Snider's Hegelian interpretation of Shakespeare, it became, after Wagoner took over the management, more and more social in orientation.<ref>{{cite book|last1=Pochmann|first1=Henry A.|title=German Culture in America|date=1957|page=289|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=wQPVnrXDNbEC|accessdate=5 August 2017}}</ref> In 1916 Wagoner curated the exhibition ''Shakespeare Tercentenary Celebration'' at the Scruggs-Vandervoort-Barney auditorium, St. Louis, of which she also curated the catalogue: curious, instructive and beautiful objects pertaining to Shakespeare and the stage.<ref>{{cite book|last1=Jansohn|first1=Christa|last2=Mehl|first2=Dieter|title=Shakespeare Jubilees: 1769–2014|date=2015|publisher=LIT Verlag Münster|page=293|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=fxq5CgAAQBAJ&pg=PA293|accessdate=5 August 2017|isbn=9783643905901}}</ref> She was also vice-president of the National Shakespeare Federation.<ref name="obituary">{{cite journal|title=St. Louis Post-Dispatch|journal=St. Louis Post-Dispatch|date=1929|page=44|url=https://www.newspapers.com/newspage/142059334/|accessdate=5 August 2017}}</ref>
On December 6, 1917, ''World News'' published ''Little Orphant Annie's Tale of the War'' by Wagoner, dedicated to the National Council of Defense.<ref>{{cite journal|title=Little Orphant Annie's Tale of the War|journal=World News|date=1917|volume=30|issue=135|url=http://virginiachronicle.com/cgi-bin/virginia?a=d&d=TWN19171206.1.6|accessdate=5 August 2017}}{{PD-notice}}</ref>
During World War I, Wagoner took part in the [[Liberty bond]] campaign and volunteered for the [[International Red Cross and Red Crescent Movement|Red Cross]].<ref name="obituary" /> In 1916 Wagoner received a letter from Elisabeth Bass, secretary of the National Woman's Liberty Loan Committee, extending congratulations and thanks for her efforts.<ref>{{cite journal|title=Fur Trade Review|journal=Fur Trade Review|volume=45|page=133|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=Iqw6AQAAMAAJ|accessdate=5 August 2017|date=February 1918}}</ref>
On August 10, 1921, Wagoner chaired the celebration commemorating Missouri's admission to the Union and was secretary of the Lafayette Celebration Committee.<ref name="obituary" />
In 1921 Wagoner contributed the essay ''A man for all ages'' for the commemorative meeting of the early Saint Louis movement in philosophy, psychology, literature, art and education, in honor of Dr. Denton J. Snider's 80th birthday, held on January 14 and 15, 1921, at the Vandervoort's Music Hall, St. Louis.<ref>{{cite web|last1=Harris|first1=David H|title=A brief report of the meeting commemorative of the early Saint Louis movement in philosophy, psychology, literature, art and education, in honor of Dr. Denton J. Snider's eightieth birthday, held January 14th and 15th, 1921, at Vandervoort's music hall, St. Louis, Missouri.|url=http://www.worldcat.org/title/brief-report-of-the-meeting-commemorative-of-the-early-saint-louis-movement-in-philosophy-psychology-literature-art-and-education-in-honor-of-dr-denton-j-sniders-eightieth-birthday-held-january-14th-and-15th-1921-at-vandervoorts-music-hall-st-louis-missouri/oclc/2007155|website=worldcat|accessdate=5 August 2017}}</ref>
==Personal life== In 1890 Adeline Myers married Harry Epply Wagoner, insurance broker and president of the Wagoner Mercantile Company, a mail order house, son of Henry Hoover Wagoner (1824–1906) and Sophronia L. Wilson.<ref>{{cite book|last1=Marquis|first1=Albert Nelson|title=The Book of St. Louisans: A Biographical Dictionary of Leading Living Men of the City of St. Louis and Vicinity|date=1912|publisher=St. Louis republic|page=615|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=MD8VAAAAYAAJ|accessdate=5 August 2017}}</ref> They had one son, Stanley Blewett (September 9, 1891 – April 16, 1949, buried at [[Bellefontaine Cemetery]]), a graduate of [[Yale College]] (B.A. 1913), where he had been most prominent during the four years, having won many gold medals in all Eastern college meets.<ref name="Johnson" /> She died on April 21, 1929. After her death, Harry Wagoner remarried with Caroline U. Hoffman, a housekeeper of the American Hotel.<ref>{{cite journal|title=Harry E. Wagoner marries American Hotel Housekeeper|journal=St. Louis Post-Dispatch|date=1930|page=7|url=https://www.newspapers.com/newspage/139017239/|accessdate=5 August 2017}}</ref><ref>{{cite journal|title=Obituary Record of Graduates of Yale University deceased during the year 1948–1949|journal=Bulletin of the Yale University|date=1950|volume=46|issue=1|url=http://mssa.library.yale.edu/obituary_record/1925_1952/1948-49.pdf|accessdate=5 August 2017}}</ref>
Wagoner won several prizes as a golf player at [[Glen Echo Country Club]] and [[Algonquin Golf Club]]. She was also an expert swimmer, diver, and equestrienne. She was winning in her manner, and kindly disposed to all.<ref name="Johnson" />
==Family== [[File:Illinois 1718.jpg|thumb|''Tamarois et Caouquias'' appears on a map of Illinois in 1718 south of the confluence of the Illinois and Mississippi rivers (approximate modern state area highlighted) from ''{{lang|fr|Carte de la Louisiane et du Cours du Mississipi}}'' by [[Guillaume de L'Isle]].]]
Angelique Chauvin Beaulieu was born in 1742, educated at Quebec, and in 1760 married Michel Beaulieu, making her home in [[Cahokia, Illinois|Cahokia]], a French-controlled town in [[Illinois Country]], where she became a social leader on account of her superior education and accomplishments. Illinois Governor Reynolds said of her, "She was the director-general in moral and medical matters; the peacemaker of the village, whose society was sought by old and young for their improvement."<ref name="Johnson">{{cite book|url=https://archive.org/details/notablewomenofst00john|title=Notable women of St. Louis, 1914|last1=Johnson|first1=Anne|date=1914|publisher=St. Louis, Woodward|page=237}}{{PD-notice}}</ref> In 1914, Wagoner wrote ''Madame Beaulieu: A Colonial Dame''.<ref>{{cite book|last1=Wagoner|first1=Adeline Palmier|title=Madame Beaulieu: A Colonial Dame|date=1914|url=https://books.google.com/books/about/Madame_Beaulieu.html?id=lTIRtwAACAAJ|accessdate=5 August 2017}}</ref>

The '''Alvarez incest case''' was uncovered late March 2009 when 59-year-old Arcedio Alvarez was arrested in [[Mariquita, Tolima|Mariquita]], [[Colombia]], accused of imprisoning and sexually abusing his daughter Alba Nidia Alvarez over a period of 25 years, beginning from when she was 9 years old.<ref>[http://news.sky.com/skynews/Home/World-News/Colombian-Fritzl-Arcebio-Alvarez-Accused-Over-Eight-Kids-With-Daughter-Alba-Nidia-Mariquita/Article/200903415251269 'Colombian Fritzl' - Eight Kids With Daughter] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20110620075058/http://news.sky.com/skynews/Home/World-News/Colombian-Fritzl-Arcebio-Alvarez-Accused-Over-Eight-Kids-With-Daughter-Alba-Nidia-Mariquita/Article/200903415251269 |date=2011-06-20 }}</ref> The daughter also gave birth to 14 children, 6 of whom died.<ref>[http://news.bbc.co.uk/2/hi/americas/7970414.stm Colombia shocked by incest case]</ref> Alvarez has been named "The monster of Mariquita" by national press.<ref>[http://www.thaindian.com/newsportal/world-news/now-colombian-fritzl-who-fathered-8-kids-with-daughter-surfaces_100172733.html Now, ‘Colombian Fritzl’ who fathered 8 kids with daughter surfaces]</ref>
== Perpetrator == Arcedio Alvarez Quintero (born in 1950) was a convicted child molester and sex offender from Mariquita, Colombia. Throughout his years in Mariquita he practiced farming with his family, becoming a farmer himself as an adult.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.diarioya.es/content/arcedio-%C3%A1lvarez-padre-de-los-11-hijos-de-su-hija|title=Arcedio Alvarez, padre de los 11 hijos de su hija|last=|first=|date=|website=Diarioya.es|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=}}</ref>
In 2009, Alvarez Quintero was prosecuted for molesting and abusing his biological daughter for years, resulting in 14 children, 6 of whom died due to malnutrition and lack of proper care. Alvarez Quintero claimed that his crimes were part of “God’s plan”<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.smh.com.au/world/colombian-fritzl-tells-daughter-their-sex-is-gods-will-20090329-9fyv.html|title=Colombian 'Fritzl' tells daughter their sex is 'God's will'|last=|first=|date=|website=smh.com|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=}}</ref> and furthermore denied any biological relationship to the victim, but this was later disproved after confirmation of his biological relationship to the victim.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.abc.net.au/news/2009-04-22/paternity-confirmed-in-colombia-incest-case/1658388|title=Paternity confirmed in Colombian incest case|last=|first=|date=|website=abc.net.au|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=}}</ref> Alvarez Quintero became known as the Monster of Mariquita, and the Colombia Fritzl, after the infamous Austrian murderer, rapist, and child molester, [[Josef Fritzl]].<ref name=":0">{{Cite web|url=http://www.semana.com/international/print-edition/articulo/the-daughter-of-the-colombian-monster/102572-3|title=The Daughter of the Colombian Monster|last=|first=|date=|website=semana.com|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=}}</ref>
== Crime == After the death of Alvarez Quintero’s wife, he began to abuse his 5-year-old daughter Nidia. The rapes are believed to have started when she was about 7 years old, and continued for roughly 26 years,<ref name=":1">{{Cite web|url=https://colombiareports.com/monster-of-mariquita-found-guilty-of-incest-and-rape/|title='Monster of Mariquita' found guilty of incest and rape|last=Alsema|first=Adriaan|date=|website=Colombiareports.com|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=}}</ref> resulting in 14 pregnancies, the first when Nidia was just 13 years old.<ref name=":1" /><ref name=":2">{{Cite web|url=http://www.cnn.com/2009/WORLD/americas/03/30/colombia.incest.charges/index.html|title=Colombian father accused of decades long incest, rape|last=Muse|first=Toby|date=|website=cnn.com|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=}}</ref> Of the 14 children to come from this abuse, 6 of them died before the prosecution due to denial of medical care by Alvarez Quintero, and of the 8 surviving children, the oldest was 19 years old at the time, and the youngest was only a few months old.<ref name=":2" /> Alvarez Quintero also never let his daughter leave their home during the time of the abuse and would often tell her that their relationship was simply “God’s will”.<ref name=":3">{{Cite web|url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/2/hi/americas/7970414.stm|title=Incest accusations shock Colombia|last=|first=|date=|website=news.bbc.co.uk|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=}}</ref> As the children grew, Alvarez Quintero began to assault his young daughters and may have been grooming his sons to do the same.<ref name=":0" /><ref name=":1" />
== Victims == Arcedio Alvarez’s victims included his daughter Alba Nidia, 35 at the time of the trial,<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://colombiareports.com/the-story-of-alba-nidia-and-her-monstruous-dad/|title=The story of Alba Nidia and her monstrous dad|last=Alsema|first=Adriaan|date=|website=colombiareports.com|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=}}</ref> and her children by him, his grandchildren. Six of their children died due to lack of needed medical attention when Alvarez refused to take them to the hospital.<ref name=":0" /> Alba Nidia herself was abused from age 5; although Alvarez reportedly taught her to read and write, he also convinced her that his abuse was acceptable.<ref name=":0" /> Alba Nidia grew up poor in a small home in central Colombian<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.reuters.com/article/us-colombia-incest/colombia-rocked-by-father-daughter-incest-case-idUSTRE52R2BW20090329|title=Colombia rocked by father-daughter incest case|last=Bronstein|first=Hugh|date=|website=reuters.com|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=}}</ref> Little information exists about her education, but she did mention in one of the reports that her father taught her how to read and write <ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.thedailybeast.com/are-there-more-dungeon-dads|title=Are there more Dungeon Dads?|last=Latza Nadeau|first=Barbie|date=|website=thedailybeast.com|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=}}</ref> Her mother died when she was young.<ref name=":2" /> Her father abused and had sexual relation lying to her and telling her what they were doing was right since she was 5 after her mother died.<ref name=":0" /> Alba Nidia was the only daughter of Arcedio Alvarez (Monster of Mariquita).<ref name=":0" /> Her children were their father’s grandchildren as well.<ref name=":2" />
== Investigation == Arcedio Alvarez was caught and arrested in March 2009 and became a convicted child molester after being charged with the heinous crimes against his daughter, whose sexual abuse and mental scarring had gone on for over 30 years.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.elmundo.es/america/2011/09/17/colombia/1316211657.html|title=Muere en prision el violador colombiano que procreo ocho hijos con su hija|last=|first=|date=|website=elmundo.es|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=}}</ref> After Alba came forward in 2009 about what had been happening to her ever since she was young, investigation revealed that most of the town where they lived knew of the suspicious things occurring and never said anything about it.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.pagina7.cl/notas/sociedad/2017/02/04/arcedio-alvarez-el-monstruo-de-mariquita-violo-y-encerro-por-30-anos-a-su-propia-hija.shtml|title=Arcedio Alvarez, el "Monstruo de Mariquita": violo y encerro por 30 anos a su propia hija|last=Schmidlin|first=Cristopher|date=|website=pagina7.cl|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=}}</ref> The investigation began when councilwoman Gilma Jimenez, brought to light the horrible conditions Alba and her children were living in with her father and how poor their health was.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.elespectador.com/articulo131959-asi-se-descubrio-arcedio-alvarez-agresor-sexual-de-su-propia-hija|title=Asi se descubrio a arcedio Alvarez, aggressor sexual de su propia hija|last=Garzon Roa|first=Olga Lucia|date=|website=elespectador.com|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=}}</ref> When this first came to light, Arcedio repeatedly claimed that Alba was only an adopted daughter and that they had agreed to their strange relationship. However, several lab tests proved that Alba Nidia was undoubtedly Arcedio’s daughter.
During the investigation, Alvarez needed police protection when attending his court dates due to the severity of his crimes and the hatred the community felt toward him. Alvarez continued to plead not guilty, claiming that Alba was adopted and that they held no biological connection at all. This case and his crimes led to changes in the Colombian law requiring those who have raped children to go to prison for life. Alvarez was found guilty of all his crimes against his daughter and her children, and was eventually sentenced to a minimum of fifteen years in prison.

| languages = [[Caribbean Hindustani|Caribbean Bhojpuri-Awadhi Hindustani (Hindi-Urdu)]]{{·}}[[Hindustani language|Manak Hindustani (Hindi-Urdu)]]{{·}}[[Sindhi language|Sindhi]]{{·}}[[Punjabi language|Punjabi]]{{·}}[[Gujarati language|Gujarati]]{{·}}[[Tamil language|Tamil]]{{·}}[[Belizean Kriol language|Kriol]]{{·}}[[English language|English]]{{·}}[[Spanish language|Spanish]] | philosophies = | religions = [[Hinduism]]{{·}}[[Islam]]{{·}}[[Sikhism]]{{·}}[[Christianity]] | related_groups = [[Indo-Jamaican]]{{·}}[[Indo-Caribbean]]{{·}}[[Indian diaspora]]{{·}}[[Belizean Kriol people|Kriols]] | footnotes = }} '''Asian Indians''', also known as '''East Indians''', are citizens of [[Belize]] of [[Indian people|Indian]] ancestry. The community made up 3.9% of the population of Belize in 2010.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.cia.gov/library/publications/the-world-factbook/geos/bh.html|title=The World Factbook — Central Intelligence Agency|website=www.cia.gov}}</ref>
[[Indian subcontinent|Asian Indians]] began arriving in Belize in the 1880s as part of the [[Indian indenture system]] set up by the [[British Raj|British Indian]] government after slavery was abolished. Initially coming in as indentured, many of them stayed on to work the sugar plantations and were joined by other Indian immigrants. [[Indian subcontinent|Indians]] are spread out over many villages and towns primarily in the Corozal and Toledo districts and live in reasonably compact rural communities. They are fairly well integrated into the Belizean population through intermarriage. However, they are still identifiable through their physiognomy and are known as 'Hindus'. These set of Indians were almost entirely composed of [[Bhojpuri people|Bhojpuris]], [[Awadhi people|Awadhis]], [[Rajasthani people|Rajasthanis]], and other [[Hindustani people|Hindustani (Hindi-Urdu)]]- speaking people of the [[Hindi Belt|Hindustani Belt]] in [[North India]]. A minority of indentured laborers were from [[South India]].
In 1907, the Canadian Government made an unsuccessful attempt to transfer Indian independence activists residing in the province of British Columbia to Belize (then known as [[British Honduras]]). A Canadian delegation led by the chief clerk of the Canadian Ministry of the Interior Harkin, and a small Indian delegation including Teja Singh traveled to British Honduras in November 1907 to determine if conditions were suitable for the move. Upon his return to Canada, Teja Singh stated that Indians were being sent to Honduras for slave-labour and claimed that Canadian officials had attempted to bribe the Indian delegation to secure a positive report. The Canadian government blamed Teja Singh's statements for the failure of the proposed transfer.<ref>{{cite book|last1=Andrew|first1=Christopher M.|last2=Noakes|first2=Jeremy|title=Intelligence and International Relations, 1900-1945|publisher=University of Exeter Press|isbn=9780859892438|page=57|url=https://books.google.co.in/books?id=z5Q_WpiT9ocC&printsec=frontcover#v=onepage&q&f=false|accessdate=19 April 2017|language=en}}</ref>

{{About|the criminal|the sportsman|Charlie Ballard}}
'''Charles W. Bullard''' was an American criminal. Known as '''Piano Charley''', he became a notorious safecracker. His name derived from his skill as a musician.<ref name=Worth>{{cite book|last=Worth|first=Richard|title=Great Robberies|year=2001|publisher=Infobase Publishing|pages=22}}</ref>
One of his criminal partnerships was with [[Adam Worth]]. In 1869, together with [[Fredericka Mandelbaum]] and others, Worth helped Bullard to escape from prison where he was serving a sentence for stealing $100,000 worth of goods from the [[Hudson River Railway Express]]. For the escape, Mandelbaum and her associates rented an office across the street from the prison and tunneled into Bullard's cell, bribing two guards to keep them quiet.<ref name=Conway>{{cite book|last=Conway|first=J. North|title=King of Heists: The Sensational Bank Robbery of 1878 That Shocked America|year=2009|publisher=Globe Pequot|pages=75–76}}</ref>
Later that year, on November 20, Bullard and Worth worked together to rob the vault of [[Boylston National Bank]] in Boston. They escaped with an estimated $200,000. However, aware of the intense police interest in the crime, they were forced to move to England and live under false names.<ref name=Worth>{{cite book|last=Worth|first=Richard|title=Great Robberies|year=2001|publisher=Infobase Publishing|pages=22}}</ref>

[[File:Prisoners world map png2.png|thumb|350px|A map of incarceration rates by country<ref name=WorldPrisonBrief/>]] [[File:US incarceration timeline-clean.svg|thumb|350px|Total United States incarceration by year]] {{See also|List of countries by incarceration rate|United States incarceration rate}} The United States has the highest prison and jail population (2,121,600 in adult facilities in 2016), and the highest incarceration rate in the world (655 per 100,000 population in 2016).<ref name=WorldPrisonBrief>[http://www.prisonstudies.org/highest-to-lowest Highest to Lowest]. [[World Prison Brief]] (WPB). Use dropdown menu to choose lists of countries by region, or the whole world. Use menu to select highest-to-lowest lists of prison population totals, prison population rates, percentage of pre-trial detainees / remand prisoners, percentage of female prisoners, percentage of foreign prisoners, and occupancy rate. Column headings in WPB tables can be clicked to reorder columns lowest to highest, or alphabetically. For detailed information for each country click on any country name in lists. See also the [http://www.prisonstudies.org/world-prison-brief-data WPB main data page] and click on the map links and/or the sidebar links to get to the region and country desired.</ref> According to the World Prison Population List (11th edition) there were around 10.35 million people in penal institutions worldwide in 2015.<ref name=WPPL11>Walmsley, Roy (2 Feb 2016). [http://www.prisonstudies.org/sites/default/files/resources/downloads/world_prison_population_list_11th_edition_0.pdf World Prison Population List (11th edition)] (PDF). From the [http://www.prisonstudies.org/research-publications?shs_term_node_tid_depth=27 Research & Publications] page of the [[World Prison Brief]] website. From page 1 of the PDF: "The information is the latest available at the end of October 2015." And from page 2: "This report shows that more than 10.35 million people are held in penal institutions throughout the world, either as pre-trial detainees/remand prisoners or having been convicted and sentenced."</ref> The US had 2,173,800 prisoners in adult facilities in 2015.<ref name=cpusa2015>[https://www.bjs.gov/index.cfm?ty=pbdetail&iid=5870 Correctional Populations in the United States, 2015]. By Danielle Kaeble and Lauren Glaze, ''BJS Statisticians.'' Dec. 2016. [[Bureau of Justice Statistics]]. See [https://www.bjs.gov/content/pub/pdf/cpus15.pdf PDF]. Page 2 says: "At yearend 2015, an estimated 2,173,800 persons were either under the jurisdiction of state or federal prisons or in the custody of local jails in the United States". See also table 4 on page 4: "Rate of persons supervised by U.S. adult correctional systems, by correctional status, 2000 and 2005–2015".</ref> That means the US held 21.0% of the world's prisoners in 2015, even though the US represented only around 4.4 percent of the world's population in 2015.<ref name=population>[https://www.census.gov/popclock Population Clock]. [[U.S. Census Bureau]]. 321,032,786 people in the US on June 30, 2015.</ref><ref>[http://www.un.org/en/development/desa/publications/world-population-prospects-2015-revision.html The World Population Prospects: 2015 Revision]. 29 July 2015 article. From [[United Nations Department of Economic and Social Affairs]]. 7.3 billion people in 2015.</ref>
Comparing other English-speaking developed countries, whereas the incarceration rate of the US is 655 per 100,000 population of all ages,<ref name=WorldPrisonBrief/> the incarceration rate of [[Canada]] is 114 per 100,000 (as of 2015),<ref name=Canada>[http://www.prisonstudies.org/country/canada Canada]. [[World Prison Brief]].</ref> [[England and Wales]] is 146 per 100,000 (as of 2016),<ref name=EnglandWales>[http://www.prisonstudies.org/country/united-kingdom-england-wales United Kingdom: England & Wales]. [[World Prison Brief]].</ref> and [[Australia]] is 160 per 100,000 (as of 2016).<ref name=Australia>[http://www.prisonstudies.org/country/australia Australia]. [[World Prison Brief]].</ref> Comparing other developed countries, the rate of [[Spain]] is 133 per 100,000 (as of 2016),<ref name=Spain>[http://www.prisonstudies.org/country/spain Spain]. [[World Prison Brief]].</ref> [[Greece]] is 89 per 100,000 (as of 2016),<ref name=Greece>[http://www.prisonstudies.org/country/greece Greece]. [[World Prison Brief]].</ref> [[Norway]] is 73 per 100,000 (as of 2016),<ref name=Norway>[http://www.prisonstudies.org/country/norway Norway]. [[World Prison Brief]].</ref> [[Netherlands]] is 69 per 100,000 (as of 2014),<ref name=Netherlands>[http://www.prisonstudies.org/country/netherlands Netherlands]. [[World Prison Brief]].</ref> and Japan is 48 per 100,000 (as of 2014).<ref name=Japan>[http://www.prisonstudies.org/country/japan Japan]. [[World Prison Brief]].</ref>
Comparing other countries with similar percentages of immigrants, [[Germany]] has a rate of 78 per 100,000 (as of 2017),<ref name=Germany>[http://www.prisonstudies.org/country/germany Germany]. [[World Prison Brief]].</ref> [[Italy]] is 96 per 100,000 (as of 2018),<ref name=Italy>[http://www.prisonstudies.org/country/Italy Italy]. [[World Prison Brief]].</ref> and [[Saudi Arabia]] is 197 per 100,000 (as of 2017).<ref name=SaudiArabia>[http://www.prisonstudies.org/country/saudi-arabia Saudi Arabia]. [[World Prison Brief]].</ref> Comparing other countries with a [[zero tolerance]] policy for illegal drugs, the rate of [[Russian Federation|Russia]] is 411 per 100,000 (as of 2018),<ref name=Russia>[http://www.prisonstudies.org/country/russian-federation Russia]. [[World Prison Brief]].</ref> [[Kazakhstan]] is 194 per 100,000 (as of 2018),<ref name=Kazakhstan>[http://www.prisonstudies.org/country/kazakhstan Kazakhstan]. [[World Prison Brief]].</ref> [[Singapore]] is 201 per 100,000 (as of 2017),<ref name=Singapore>[http://www.prisonstudies.org/country/singapore Singapore]. [[World Prison Brief]].</ref> and [[Sweden]] is 57 per 100,000 (as of 2016).<ref name=Sweden>[http://www.prisonstudies.org/country/sweden Sweden]. [[World Prison Brief]].</ref>
The incarceration rate of the [[People's Republic of China]] varies depending on sources and measures. According to the [[World Prison Brief]], the rate for only sentenced prisoners is 118 per 100,000 (as of 2015). The rate for prisoners including estimations for the number of pre-trial detainees and those in administrative detention is 164 per 100,000 (as of 2015).<ref name=China>[http://www.prisonstudies.org/country/china China]. [[World Prison Brief]].</ref> In a 2010 interview [[Harry Wu]], a U.S.-based [[human rights]] activist and ex-Chinese [[labor camp]] prisoner, estimates that "in the last 60 years, more than 40–50 million people" were in Chinese labor camps,<ref>{{cite interview |last=Wu |first=Harry |subjectlink=Harry Wu |interviewer=Chris Johnstone |title=One on One |url=http://www.radio.cz/en/section/one-on-one/chinese-prison-camp-victim-and-human-rights-activist-harry-wu |type=Interview: audio |work=Radio Prague |publisher=Český rozhlas 7 |location=Prague, Czech Republic |date=1 March 2010 |accessdate=2011-04-14}}</ref> but that period includes the [[Campaign to Suppress Counterrevolutionaries|mass incarcerations of the 1950s]] or the [[Cultural Revolution]] (1966-1976) and is not representative of modern China.
== U.S. incarceration rate peaked in 2008 == [[File:World prison population 2008.svg|thumb|350px|U.S. incarceration rate peaked in 2008. Prisoners per 100,000 population.<ref name=icps8>Walmsley, Roy (30 Jan 2009). [http://www.prisonstudies.org/sites/default/files/resources/downloads/wppl-8th_41.pdf World Prison Population List (8th Edition)]. From [http://www.prisonstudies.org/research-publications?shs_term_node_tid_depth=27 World Prison Population Lists]. By [[World Prison Brief]]. "The information is the latest available in early December 2008. … Most figures relate to dates between the beginning of 2006 and the end of November 2008." According to the summary on page one there were 2.29 million U.S. inmates and 9.8 million inmates worldwide. The U.S. held 23.4% of the world's inmates. The U.S. total in this report is for December 31, 2007 (see page 3), and does not include inmates in juvenile detention facilities.</ref><ref name=cpusa2013/>]] [[File:US adult correctional population timeline.gif|thumb|350px|Total US incarceration peaked in 2008. Total correctional population peaked in 2007.<ref name=cpusa2013/>]] [[File:US incarceration and correctional population rates over time.jpg|thumb|350px|US incarceration and correctional population rates over time. The incarceration rate peaked in 2008.<ref name=cpusa2015/>]] [[File:United States correctional population.svg|thumb|350px|US correctional population ([[prison]], [[jail]], [[probation]], [[parole]]).]]
Total US incarceration (prisons and jails) peaked in 2008. On January 1, 2008 more than 1 in 100 adults in the United States were in prison or jail.<ref name=pewcenterstudy>[http://www.pewtrusts.org/en/research-and-analysis/reports/2008/02/28/one-in-100-behind-bars-in-america-2008 One in 100: Behind Bars in America 2008]. February 28, 2008. [[Pew Charitable Trusts|The Pew Center on the States]].</ref><ref name=nytimes2008feb>[[Liptak, Adam]] (28 Feb 2008). [https://www.nytimes.com/2008/02/28/us/28cnd-prison.html 1 in 100 U.S. Adults Behind Bars, New Study Says]. ''[[New York Times]]''.</ref> Total correctional population ([[prison]], [[jail]], [[probation]], [[parole]]) peaked in 2007.<ref name=cpusa2013>[http://www.bjs.gov/index.cfm?ty=pbdetail&iid=5177 Correctional Populations in the United States, 2013] (NCJ 248479). Published December 2014 by [[U.S. Bureau of Justice Statistics]] (BJS). By Lauren E. Glaze and Danielle Kaeble, BJS statisticians. See [http://www.bjs.gov/content/pub/pdf/cpus13.pdf PDF]. See page 1 "highlights" section for the "1 in ..." numbers. See table 1 on page 2 for adult numbers. See table 2 on page 3 for a timeline of incarceration rates. See table 5 on page 6 for male and female numbers. See appendix table 5 on page 13, for "Estimated number of persons supervised by adult correctional systems, by correctional status, 2000–2013." See appendix table 2: "Inmates held in custody in state or federal prisons or in local jails, 2000 and 2012–2013".</ref> If all prisoners are counted (including [[Youth incarceration in the United States|juvenile]], territorial, [[U.S. Immigration and Customs Enforcement|ICE]], Indian country, and military), then in 2008 the USA had around 24.7% of the world's 9.8 million prisoners.<ref name=prisoners2008>[http://bjs.ojp.usdoj.gov/index.cfm?ty=pbdetail&iid=1763 Prisoners in 2008]. (NCJ 228417). December 2009 report from the [[U.S. Bureau of Justice Statistics]] (BJS). By William J. Sabol, Ph.D. and Heather C. West, Ph.D., BJS Statisticians. Also, Matthew Cooper, BJS Intern. See [http://bjs.ojp.usdoj.gov/content/pub/pdf/p08.pdf PDF]. Table 9 on page 8 has the number of inmates in state or federal prison facilities, local jails, U.S. territories, military facilities, [[U.S. Immigration and Customs Enforcement]] (ICE) owned and contracted facilities, jails in Indian country, and [[Youth incarceration in the United States|juvenile facilities]] (2006 Census of Juveniles in Residential Placement). See 2007 juvenile total [[:File:Total juvenile detention chart for the USA.gif|here]]. Table 8 on page 8 has the incarceration rates for 2000, 2007, and 2008.</ref><ref name=cjrp>Sickmund, M., Sladky, T.J., Kang, W., & Puzzanchera, C.. "[http://www.ojjdp.gov/ojstatbb/ezacjrp/ Easy Access to the Census of Juveniles in Residential Placement]". Click "National Crosstabs" at the top, and then choose the census years. Click "Show table" to get the total number of juvenile inmates for those years. Or go '''[http://www.ojjdp.gov/ojstatbb/ezacjrp/asp/display.asp here]''' for all the years. [[Office of Juvenile Justice and Delinquency Prevention]].</ref><ref name=icps8/>
A 2008 ''[[New York Times]]'' article,<ref name=nyt2008apr23>[[Liptak, Adam]] (23 Apr 2008). [https://www.nytimes.com/2008/04/23/us/23prison.html?pagewanted=print Inmate Count in US Dwarfs Other Nations']. [http://www.mapinc.org/drugnews/v08/n417/a04.html]. ''[[New York Times]].''</ref> said that "it is the length of sentences that truly distinguishes American prison policy. Indeed, the mere number of sentences imposed here would not place the United States at the top of the incarceration lists. If lists were compiled based on annual admissions to prison per capita, several European countries would outpace the United States. But American prison stays are much longer, so the total incarceration rate is higher."
== More comparisons ==
In the United States, [[Incarceration of women in the United States|women make up more than one tenth]] of the whole prison population.<ref>{{cite book|last=Carlen|first=Pat|title=Analysing Women's Imprisonment|year=2004|publisher=Willan Publishing|location=Portland|page=43}}</ref> In most countries, the proportion of female inmates to the larger population is closer to one in twenty. Australia is the exception where the rate of female imprisonment increased from 9.2 percent in 1991 to 15.3 percent in 1999.<ref>{{cite book |last=Carlen |first=Pat |title=Analysing Women's Imprisonment |year=2004 |publisher=Willan Publishing |location=Portland |page=42}}</ref>
In addition, the United States has significant [[Race and crime in the United States|racial disparities in rates of incarceration]].<ref name=rehavi>Rehavi and Starr (2012) [http://papers.ssrn.com/sol3/papers.cfm?abstract_id=1985377 "Racial Disparity in Federal Criminal Charging and Its Sentencing Consequences"] Working Paper Series, no. 12-002 (Univ. of Michigan Law & Economics, Empirical Legal Studies Center)</ref> According to [[Michelle Alexander]], the United States "imprisons a larger percentage of its black population than South Africa did at the height of apartheid".<ref name=newjimcrow>[[Alexander, Michelle]] (2010). [[The New Jim Crow: Mass Incarceration in the Age of Colorblindness]]. The New Press, New York. See pages 7 and 86. {{ISBN|978-1-59558-643-8}}. Look or [https://www.amazon.com/The-New-Crow-Incarceration-Colorblindness/dp/1595586431#reader_1595586431 search inside].</ref> The black imprisonment rate of South Africa could not have come close to today’s American rate simply due to limited room. Notably, there’s something of an international theme in countries comparing themselves to apartheid South Africa. There were instances where Australian journalists were drawing the same contrast relative to rates of imprisonment in their country.<ref>Greenberg, Jon. [http://www.politifact.com/punditfact/statements/2014/dec/11/nicholas-kristof/kristof-us-imprisons-blacks-rates-higher-south-afr Kristof: U.S. imprisons blacks at rates higher than South Africa during apartheid]. [[Politifact]].</ref> In the Huffington Post piece "Mass Incarceration's Failure", attorney Antonio Moore states "The incarceration rate for young black men ages 20 to 39, is nearly 10,000 per 100,000. To give context, during the racial discrimination of apartheid in South Africa, the prison rate for black male South Africans, rose to 851 per 100,000."<ref name=Moore2015>Moore, Antonio (4 Aug 2015). [http://www.huffingtonpost.com/antonio-moore/the-fallout-from-american_b_7919712.html Mass Incarceration's Failure: America's Bias in Arrest, Conviction and Sentencing]. ''[[Huffington Post]].''</ref>
A major contributor to the high incarceration rates is the length of the [[prison sentence]]s in the United States. One of the criticisms of the United States system is that it has much longer sentences than any other part of the world. The typical [[mandatory sentence]] for a first-time drug offense in federal court is five or ten years, compared to other developed countries around the world where a first time offense would warrant at most 6 months in jail. <ref name=newjimcrow/> Mandatory sentencing prohibits judges from using their discretion and forces them to place longer sentences on nonviolent offenses than they normally would do.
Even though there are other countries that have a higher rate of committing inmates to prison annually, the fact that the United States keeps their prisoners longer causes the total incarceration rate to become higher. To give an example, the average [[burglary]] sentence in the United States is 16 months, compared to 5 months in [[Canada]] and 7 months in [[England]].<ref name=nyt2008apr23/>
The US incarceration rate peaked in 2008 when about 1 in 100 US adults was behind bars.<ref name=nytimes2008feb/> This incarceration rate exceeded the average incarceration levels in the [[Soviet Union]] during the existence of the infamous [[Gulag]] system, when the [[Demography of the Soviet Union|Soviet Union's population]] reached 168 million, and 1.2 to 1.5 million people were in the [[Gulag]] prison camps and colonies (i.e. about 0.8 imprisoned per 100 USSR residents, according to numbers from [[Anne Applebaum]] and [[Steven Rosefielde]]).<ref>{{cite book|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=L4s1H9v2yOwC&pg=PA95&lpg=PA95&dq=gulag+population#v=onepage&q=gulag%20population&f=false|title=The Russian economy: from Lenin to Putin. By Steven Rosefielde|isbn=978-1-4051-1337-3|author1=Rosefielde|first1=Steven|year=2007}}</ref><ref>{{cite book|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=8fIfmxAs_T0C&pg=PA446&lpg=PA446&dq=gulag+total+population#v=onepage&q=gulag%20total%20population&f=false|title=Gulag: a history. By Anne Applebaum|isbn=978-0-7679-0056-0|author1=Applebaum|first1=Anne|year=2003}}</ref> Some of the latter Soviet Union's yearly incarceration rates from 1934 to 1953, however, likely were the world's historically highest for a [[modern age]] country<ref>{{cite web |last1=Getty |first1=J. Arch |last2=Rittersporn |first2=Gabor T. |last3=Zemskov |first3=Viktor N. |title=Victims of the Soviet Penal System in the Pre-war Years: A First Approach on the Basis of Archival Evidence |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20081228031043/http://www.etext.org/Politics/Staljin/Staljin/articles/AHR/AHR.html |website=EText (archived) |accessdate=28 December 2008}}</ref>. In ''[[The New Yorker]]'' article ''The Caging of America'' (2012), [[Adam Gopnik]] writes: "Over all, there are now more people under 'correctional supervision' in America—more than six million—than were in the [[Gulag]] under [[Stalin]] at its height."<ref>Gopnik, Adam (30 January 2012). [http://www.newyorker.com/magazine/2012/01/30/the-caging-of-america The Caging of America]. ''[[The New Yorker]].''</ref>

[[File:Drug disposal receptacle.jpg|thumb|This is a drug disposal receptacle in the lobby of a hospital.It is a product which commercial company Inmar sells to health care providers who wish to present a [https://www.inmar.com/inmar-solution/consumer-drug-take-back-program/ Consumer Drug Take-Back Program].]] '''Drug disposal''' is the discarding of drugs. Individuals commonly dispose of [[unused drugs]] that remain after the end of medical treatment.<ref name="Ginger 2017">{{cite web|url=http://www.consumerreports.org/drugs/getting-rid-of-expired-medication/|title=Easy Steps for Getting Rid of Unused Medication|last1=Skinner|first1=Ginger|date=20 March 2017|website=[[Consumer Reports]]|accessdate=30 March 2017}}</ref> Health care organizations dispose of drugs on a larger scale for a range of reasons, including having leftover drugs after treating patients and discarding of expired drugs. Failure to properly dispose of drugs creates opportunities for others (of whom the drug is unintended) to take them inappropriately.<ref name="Ginger 2017"/> Inappropriate disposal of drugs can also cause [[drug pollution]].<ref name="Ginger 2017"/>
People dispose of drugs in various ways; even organizations with expertise on drugs may give inconsistent information to consumers about drug disposal.<ref>{{cite journal|last1=Kuspis|first1=DA|last2=Krenzelok|first2=EP|title=What happens to expired medications? A survey of community medication disposal.|journal=Veterinary and human toxicology|date=February 1996|volume=38|issue=1|pages=48–9|pmid=8825752}}</ref>
==Sources of drugs== Medication waste includes both hazardous and non-hazardous waste, controlled substances, and expired pharmaceuticals.<ref name=":5">{{Cite web|url=https://www.state.nj.us/dep/enforcement/1%20RCRA%20Pharmaceutical%20Waste%20-%20Best%20Management%20Practices%20-Vona%205-17-12.pdf|title=Pharmaceutical Waste Compliance For Healthcare Facilities|last=|first=|date=17 May 2012|website=The Official Website for the State of New Jersey|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=}}</ref>
Medication waste can come from multiple levels in the drug's lifespan. First, it can come from production factories from where they were created. This includes unwanted pharmaceutical ingredients and materials that can no longer be used in the drug manufacturing process.<ref name=":6">{{Cite web|url=http://www.thepharmajournal.com/archives/2017/vol6issue3/PartC/6-2-9-174.pdf|title=An Overview of Waste Management in Pharmaceutical Industry|last=Jaseem|first=Mohammed|date=2017|website=The Pharma Journal|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=}}</ref> Second, medication waste can be generated from healthcare facilities including hospitals, clinics, and pharmacies. Medication waste from this source can be from over prescribing of drugs from healthcare providers, hospital labs, expired drugs, opened drug containers and partially used medications.<ref name=":5" /> Furthermore, these wastes can include materials, such as syringes, vials, IV bags, and tubing that contain excess drugs or contaminated in the process of handling hazardous pharmaceuticals, such as chemotherapy drugs.<ref name=":6" /> Some states have regulations that require healthcare facilities to destroy unused medications.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.epa.gov/sites/production/files/2015-11/documents/unused-pharms-health-care_interim-report_2008.pdf|title=Unused Pharmaceuticals in the Health Care Industry: Interim Report|last=|first=|date=November 2011|website=United States Environmental Protection Agency|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=}}</ref> Lastly, pharmaceutical waste can come from excessive consumption of over-the-counter medications from patients.<ref name=":3">{{Cite web|url=https://fip.org/files/fip/publications/2015-12-Green-Pharmacy-Practice.pdf|title=Taking Responsibility for the Environmental Impact of Medicines|last=|first=|date=2015|website=FIP|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=1 November 2018}}</ref>
Sometimes normal use of a drug can result in waste. For example, when someone uses a [[dermal patch]], after the patch is used, it will still retain significant potency, necessitating safe disposal.<ref name="Commissioner April 2016">{{cite web|author1=Office of the Commissioner|title=Consumer Updates - How to Dispose of Unused Medicines|url=https://www.fda.gov/ForConsumers/ConsumerUpdates/ucm101653.htm|website=www.fda.gov|accessdate=30 March 2017|language=en|date=25 April 2016}}</ref>
==Reasons for disposal of drugs== Medical authorities advise that consumers not store any drug that they would not have a reason at present to possess.<ref name="Ginger 2017"/> Storing drugs creates a possibility that someone will use them inappropriately and suffer harm.<ref name="Ginger 2017"/> Accidental ingestion of medications prescribed for another individual is a leading source of poisonings in American households. According to Poison Control Centers in the United States, in 2007 approximately 23,783 of 255,732 cases involving inappropriate medication use were associated with inadvertent exposure.<ref name=":1">{{Cite journal|last=Bronstein|first=Alvin C.|last2=Spyker|first2=Daniel A.|last3=Jr|first3=Louis R. Cantilena|last4=Green|first4=Jody L.|last5=Rumack|first5=Barry H.|last6=Heard|first6=Stuart E.|date=2008-01-01|title=2007 Annual Report of the American Association of Poison Control Centers' National Poison Data System (NPDS): 25th Annual Report|url=https://dx.doi.org/10.1080/15563650802559632|journal=Clinical Toxicology|volume=46|issue=10|pages=927–1057|doi=10.1080/15563650802559632|issn=1556-3650|pmid=19065310}}</ref> 5,000 of these cases involved children under the age of 6 years old.<ref name=":1" /> Due to the variations in the way children's bodies metabolize drugs, medication poisoning in children can be extremely fatal.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.fda.gov/Drugs/ResourcesForYou/Consumers/BuyingUsingMedicineSafely/EnsuringSafeUseofMedicine/SafeDisposalofMedicines/ucm186188.htm|title=Safe Disposal of Medicines - Medicine Disposal: Questions and Answers|last=Research|first=Center for Drug Evaluation and|website=www.fda.gov|language=en|access-date=2017-11-15}}</ref>
==Methods for disposal==
===Disposal for individuals and communities=== The most obvious way for individuals to dispose of drugs is through the household [[waste management]] service.<ref name="Ginger 2017"/> Experts advise checking other options first, because simply discarding drugs with other trash creates the possibility that someone could use them and be harmed.<ref name="Ginger 2017"/> Medical authorities recommend against disposing of drugs by passing them on to other consumers.<ref name="Commissioner April 2016"/>
The best source of local advice will be the community pharmacy.<ref name="Ginger 2017"/> Pharmacies already handle drugs and will recommend what sort of disposal method is most appropriate.<ref name="Ginger 2017"/> Many pharmacies will collect drugs and dispose of them as a community service.<ref name="Ginger 2017"/> Some regions have special government services that offer to take back and dispose of drugs.<ref name="Ginger 2017"/> Sometimes, either a pharmacy or government service will provide a way to mail drugs to a special drug disposal facility.<ref name="Ginger 2017"/> If there are no other options and one must put drugs into the trash, a recommended safer way to do so is by mixing the drug with unattractive trash.<ref name="Ginger 2017"/> Putting pills into the toilet can cause drug pollution, but this might be justified as a way to quickly disposing of dangerous drugs.<ref name="Ginger 2017"/>
There have been many attempts in the United States to encourage consumers to bring their leftover drugs to disposal centers.<ref name="Egan 2016">{{cite journal|last1=Egan|first1=Kathleen L.|last2=Gregory|first2=Eric|last3=Sparks|first3=Michael|last4=Wolfson|first4=Mark|title=From dispensed to disposed: evaluating the effectiveness of disposal programs through a comparison with prescription drug monitoring program data|journal=The American Journal of Drug and Alcohol Abuse|date=31 October 2016|volume=43|issue=1|pages=69–77|doi=10.1080/00952990.2016.1240801}}</ref> Some examples of disposal programs include having a special event at a community center with prior advertisements for people to bring their drugs to the event, or otherwise educating individuals and concerned organizations about the correct way to dispose of drugs.<ref name="Egan 2016"/> One study reviewing the efficacy of these programs found that their impact was too low to have the desired result of decreasing community access to leftover drugs.<ref name="Egan 2016"/>
===Disposal for organizations and industry=== Disposal of large amounts of drugs can cause [[drug pollution]] and negatively impact the [[Environmental impact of pharmaceuticals and personal care products|environment]].<ref name="WHO 1999">{{cite book|author1=World Health Organization|title=Guidelines for safe disposal of unwanted pharmaceuticals in and after emergencies|date=1999|publisher=World Health Organization|isbn=978-0119854985|url=http://apps.who.int/medicinedocs/pdf/whozip51e/whozip51e.pdf}}</ref> Organizations might choose to dispose of large amounts of drugs by returning them to the manufacturer, putting them in [[landfills]], using [[Incineration]], or dumping the drugs into sewers.<ref name="WHO 1999"/>
==Disposal of controversial drugs== Drugs associated with [[substance abuse]] and [[Prohibition of drugs|prohibited drug]]<nowiki/>s receive special attention in their disposal.<ref name="CBS May 2014">{{cite web|author1=Crimesider Staff|title=How are authorities destroying seized drugs?|url=http://www.cbsnews.com/news/how-are-authorities-destroying-seized-drugs/|accessdate=5 May 2017|language=en|date=26 May 2014}}</ref> The police might seize such drugs as [[contraband]], and then have to destroy them.<ref name="CBS May 2014"/> In other cases, some legal drugs create risks for abuse and need more attention in disposal than drugs that are not attractive for abuse.<ref name="Herring 2008">{{cite journal|last1=Herring|first1=ME|last2=Shah|first2=SK|last3=Shah|first3=SK|last4=Gupta|first4=AK|title=Current regulations and modest proposals regarding disposal of unused opioids and other controlled substances.|journal=The Journal of the American Osteopathic Association|date=July 2008|volume=108|issue=7|pages=338–43|pmid=18648027}}</ref> It is challenging for governments to discuss how to properly dispose of controversial drugs.<ref name="Herring 2008"/>
One small regional study in the United States reported the outcomes of a public health program to take back unused opioids.<ref name="Welham 2015">{{cite journal|last1=Welham|first1=Grace C.|last2=Mount|first2=Jeanine K.|last3=Gilson|first3=Aaron M.|title=Type and Frequency of Opioid Pain Medications Returned for Disposal|journal=Drugs - Real World Outcomes|date=4 March 2015|volume=2|issue=2|pages=129–135|doi=10.1007/s40801-015-0019-4}}</ref> This study found that individuals who returned opioids tended to return more than half of what they were prescribed, which could be an indication that these people had twice as much medication as they wanted.<ref name="Welham 2015"/> The study was too limited to form a general conclusion, but it provided information to guide further discussion and research on whether people would participate in opioid take back programs, what sorts of drugs are more likely to be returned, and how much people would return.<ref name="Welham 2015"/>
There is a list of medications in which the [[Food and Drug Administration|U.S. Food and Drug Administration]] recommends to be disposed of via flushing down the toilet if consumers are unable to take these drugs to a drug take-back program. These medications contain controlled substances that are dangerous to pets and other people in the home and should be disposed of immediately when no longer needed. Examples include [[Dilaudid]] (hydromorphone hydrochloride) tablets, fentanyl patches and [[morphine sulfate]] oral solution.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.fda.gov/Drugs/ResourcesForYou/Consumers/BuyingUsingMedicineSafely/EnsuringSafeUseofMedicine/SafeDisposalofMedicines/ucm576167.htm|title=Flushing of Certain Medicines|last=|first=|date=6 October 2017|website=U.S. Food and Drug Administration|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=30 October 2017}}</ref> These products should immediately flush due to high potential for abuse and overdose.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.pharmacist.com/proper-disposal-fentanyl-patches-can-save-lives-0|title=Proper disposal of fentanyl patches can save lives|website=www.pharmacist.com|language=en|access-date=2018-11-21}}</ref>
== Worldwide Drug Disposal Practices ==
=== European Union === In 2001, the European Parliament released a [[Directive 2001/83/EC|Directive]] regarding the disposal practices of medicinal products.<ref name=":4">{{Cite web|url=https://eur-lex.europa.eu/LexUriServ/LexUriServ.do?uri=CELEX:32001L0083:EN:HTML|title=EUR-Lex - 32001L0083 - EN|website=eur-lex.europa.eu|language=EN|access-date=2018-11-02}}</ref> Directive 2001/83/EC stated that the outer packaging of medications needed to include special disposal precautions.<ref name=":4" /> In 2004, the EU put out another directive that further clarified the 2001 directive and called for establishment of medication collection protocols and information regarding specific collection protocols for the state or country be placed on the packaging.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://ec.europa.eu/health/sites/health/files/files/eudralex/vol-1/dir_2004_27/dir_2004_27_en.pdf|title=Public Health - European Commission|last=|first=|date=|website=Public Health|language=en|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=2018-11-02}}</ref> ====United Kingdom==== As outlined in National Health Service SI 2014/349: The National Health Service (Pharmaceutical and Local Pharmaceutical Services) Regulations 2013, local pharmacies are obligated to take back unused and unwanted medications generated in the home.<ref name=":7">{{Cite web|url=https://www.legislation.gov.uk/uksi/2013/349/contents/made|title=The National Health Service (Pharmaceutical and Local Pharmaceutical Services) Regulations 2013|website=www.legislation.gov.uk|language=en|access-date=2018-11-02}}</ref> Per these same regulations, pharmacies are responsible for sorting the medications and returning them to the NHS.<ref name=":7" />
=== Canada === Canada has no specific nationwide drug take back or disposal policy, but most provinces have individual plans.<ref>Health Canada. Pharmaceutical disposal programs for the public: A Canadian perspective. Health Canada environmental impact initiative. 2009. http://c.ymcdn.com/sites/www.productstewardship.us/resource/resmgr/imported/Takeback%20(2).pdf. Accessed 2018-11-01</ref>Most pharmacies in Canada can take back unused and expired medications any day of the year.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.canada.ca/en/health-canada/services/safe-disposal-prescription-drugs.html|title=Safe disposal of prescription drugs - Canada.ca|last=Canada|first=Health|website=www.canada.ca|language=en|access-date=2018-11-21}}</ref>
== National Regulations in the United States == In the United States, used prescriptions are serious safety concerns because they can be accidentally ingested, overdosed or diverted for illegal use.
To address these concerns, the Drug Enforcement Administration (DEA) created National Prescription Drug Take Back Days that occurs twice annually in April and October.<ref name=":0" /> These Take Back Days are part of a mission to create safe medication disposal sites, prevent [[drug diversion]] or transfer of the prescribed drug for illicit use, and provide education for the public.<ref name=":0">{{Cite web|url=https://www.deadiversion.usdoj.gov/drug_disposal/takeback/|title=National Prescription Drug Take Back Day|website=www.deadiversion.usdoj.gov|language=en-US|access-date=2017-10-30}}</ref> In April 2017, the 13th National Drug Take Back Day included 5,498 collection sites across the country and 450 tons unused or expired prescription medicines were collected.<ref name=":0" /> Additionally, The National Association of Drug Diversion Investigators (NADDI) sponsors a website to locate Rx Drug Drop Boxes for safe medication disposal outside of National Prescription Drug Take Back Days.
=== Secure and Responsible Drug Disposal Act of 2010 === The "Secure and Responsible Drug Disposal Act of 2010" was proposed to amend the "Controlled Substances Act" created in 1970 which prohibits the disposal of controlled substances unless a member of law enforcement has authorization from the DEA to directly receive and dispose of the controlled substance. This bars drug take back programs from being able to receive and dispose of controlled medications for members of the public, which in turn can lead to the potential misuse of these drugs. Misuse of prescription medications has been a growing epidemic, with deaths from opioids quadrupling since 1999.<ref>{{cite web|last1=CDC|title=Drug overdose deaths in the United States continue to increase in 2015|url=https://www.cdc.gov/drugoverdose/epidemic/index.html|website=cdc.gov|accessdate=9 November 2017}}</ref> It was shown that in 2006, about 1/3 of new prescription drug abusers were 12-17 year olds.<ref name=":8">{{cite web|last1=One Hundred Eleventh Congress of the United States of America|title=An Act|url=https://www.deadiversion.usdoj.gov/drug_disposal/non_registrant/s_3397.pdf|accessdate=5 January 2010}}</ref> With these statistics, Congress decided to take an active role in trying to make drug take back programs more readily available. Therefore, the "Secure and Responsible Drug Disposal Act of 2010" was created to allow the Attorney General permission in creating new policies to provide citizens “convenient and safe” disposal of their unwanted medications to authorized people or facilities.<ref name=":8" /> Congress created this act with a goal of preventing drug diversion and environmental harm/pollution by these drugs.<ref name=":8" />
=== Other Take Back Programs === In addition to the drug disposal of 2012, other national agencies have also promoted the use of the drug take back programs. In 2011, White House announced the first national Prescription Abuse Prevention Plan. The Prescription Abuse Prevention Plan expanded support to the prescription drug disposal programs and decreased the supply of unused prescription drugs.<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.whitehouse.gov/ondcp/|title=Office of National Drug Control Policy|work=The White House|access-date=2018-11-02|language=en-US}}</ref> The Environmental Protection Agency also encouraged the use of prescription drug disposal programs with guidelines for household disposal of medication and recommendations on the incineration of the household pharmaceutical product.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.epa.gov/hwgenerators/collecting-and-disposing-unwanted-medicines|title=Collecting and Disposing of Unwanted Medicines {{!}} US EPA|last=EPA,OSWER,ORCR|first=US|website=US EPA|language=en|access-date=2018-11-02}}</ref> The American Pharmacist Association and Pharmaceutical Research and Manufacturers of America also partnered with the U.S. Fish and Wildlife Service to raise awareness for consumers to properly dispose medication. The campaign encouraged consumer to not flush unused medications or pour them down the sink. The campaign also recognized pharmacists' role to inform consumers of the different disposal techniques and which medications are appropriate for flushing.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.pharmacist.com/letter-usfws-and-apha-collaboration|title=Letter of USFWS and APhA Collaboration|website=www.pharmacist.com|language=en|access-date=2018-11-02}}</ref>
==Examples of State Regulations==
=== Alameda County Safe Drug Disposal Ordinance === Alameda County was the first county in the United States to make the manufacturer pay for safe disposal of pharmaceutical waste. This ordinance required companies that manufacture drugs sold and distributed in Alameda County must operate and pay for a "Product Stewardship Program."<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://library.municode.com/ca/alameda_county/codes/code_of_ordinances?searchRequest=%7B%22searchText%22:%22Medication%20Disposal%22,%22pageNum%22:1,%22resultsPerPage%22:25,%22booleanSearch%22:false,%22stemming%22:true,%22fuzzy%22:false,%22synonym%22:false,%22contentTypes%22:%5B%22CODES%22%5D,%22productIds%22:%5B%5D%7D&nodeId=TIT6HESA_CH6.53ALCOSADRDIOR|title=Municode Library|website=library.municode.com|language=en|access-date=2018-11-01}}</ref> Examples of these programs include a drug kiosk or mail-back program and volunteer collectors, such as law enforcement and pharmacies.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.acgov.org/aceh/safedisposal/#ordinance|title=Safe Drug and Consumer-Generated Sharps Disposal - Alameda County Environmental Health - Alameda County|website=www.acgov.org|access-date=2018-11-01}}</ref> Due to this program 8 other counties in California adopted similar programs, including San Mateo, Santa Barbara, Santa Clara, Marin, Los Angeles, Santa Cruz, Sonoma, Contra Costa, San Luis Obispo, and Tehama Counties.<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://calpsc.org/products/pharmaceuticals/city-county-ordinances-safe-disposal-sharps-pharmaceuticals/|title=City and County Ordinances for Safe Disposal of Sharps and Pharmaceuticals - California Product Stewardship Council|work=California Product Stewardship Council|access-date=2018-11-01|language=en-US}}</ref>
===California State Board of Pharmacy=== In California, entities including pharmacies in retail and hospital settings may host drug take-back programs as long as they follow requirements under Article 9.1 of Division 17 of Title 16 of the California Code of Regulations.<ref name="CASBOP">{{cite web|last1=California|first1=State Board of Pharmacy|title=California SBOP - Prescription Drug Take-Back Services|url=http://www.pharmacy.ca.gov/laws_regs/1776_oa.pdf}}</ref> These pharmacies are required to register with the Drug Enforcement Administration (DEA) and notify the Board of Pharmacy and DEA within 30 days of starting or stopping a program.<ref name="CASBOP"/> These pharmacies must have collection receptacles located in authorized locations and have liners that are certified to meet American Society for Testing Materials standards.<ref name="CASBOP" /> The pharmacies must also follow protocols like accepting prescription drugs to be sent back to an authorized DEA destruction site and no employee can be part of the program if they have a history with controlled substance-related felonies.<ref name="CASBOP"/> The pharmacy may not sort, count, or review the unwanted prescription medications once collected and they are required to report tampering of any receptacles to the Board of Pharmacy within 14 days.<ref name="CASBOP"/> It is important to note that these pharmaceutical take-back programs only take prescription medications, not drug samples or medical waste.<ref name="CASBOP"/>
=== California Senate Bill 212 === On September 30, 2018, California passed SB 212: Solid waste: pharmaceutical and sharps waste stewardship.<ref name=":2">{{Cite web|url=https://leginfo.legislature.ca.gov/faces/billTextClient.xhtml?bill_id=201720180SB212|title=Bill Text - SB-212 Solid waste: pharmaceutical and sharps waste stewardship.|website=leginfo.legislature.ca.gov|access-date=2018-11-01}}</ref> Similar to the Alameda County Ordinance, this is a statewide drug and needle program funded by manufacturers or distributors. The bill requires that these entities create their own stewardship program or be part of a stewardship program, which will be approved by CalRecycle.<ref name=":2" /> The bill mandates a minimum of 5 collection sites per county or if the county is larger it requires 1 per 50,000 people.<ref name=":2" /> They also require retail pharmacies to serve as an "authorized collector." Authorized collectors serve their counties in one location or 15% of store locations in the county, depending which is greater.<ref name=":2" /> The bill will begin January 2019, with approvals by CalRecyle completed and implementation of the programs started January 2021.<ref name=":2" />

{{Further|Early modern Europe}} {{Human history|222}}
The '''early modern period''' of [[modern history]] follows the [[late Middle Ages]] of the [[post-classical era]]. Although the chronological limits of the period are open to debate, the [[timeline|timeframe]] spans the period after the late portion of the [[post-classical age]] (c. 1500), known as the [[Middle Ages]], through the beginning of the [[Age of Revolutions]] (c. 1800) and is variously demarcated by historians as beginning with the [[Fall of Constantinople]] in 1453, with the [[Renaissance]] period, and with the [[Age of Discovery]] (especially with the [[voyages of Christopher Columbus]] beginning in 1492, but also with [[Vasco da Gama]]'s [[Vasco da Gama#First voyage|discovery of the sea route to the East]] in 1498), and ending around the [[French Revolution]] in 1789.
Historians in recent decades have argued that from a worldwide standpoint, the most important feature of the early modern period was its [[proto-globalization|globalizing]] character.<ref>Jan De Vries, "The limits of globalization in the early modern world." ''Economic History Review'' (2010) 63#3 pp: 710–733.</ref> The period witnessed the exploration and colonization of [[the Americas]] and the rise of sustained contacts between previously isolated parts of the globe. The [[historical power]]s became involved in global trade, as the exchange of goods, plants, animals, and food crops extended to the [[Old World]] and the [[New World]]. The [[Columbian Exchange]] greatly affected the human environment.
New economies and institutions emerged, becoming more sophisticated and globally articulated over the course of the early modern period. This process began in the medieval North Italian [[city-states]], particularly [[Genoa]], [[Venice]], and [[Milan]]. The early modern period also included the rise of the dominance of the economic theory of [[mercantilism]]. The [[European colonialism|European colonization]] of the Americas, Asia, and Africa occurred during the 15th to 19th centuries, and [[History of Christianity#Catholic missions|spread Christianity]] around the world.
The early modern trends in various regions of the world represented a shift away from medieval modes of organization, politically and economically. [[Feudalism]] declined in Europe, while the period also included the [[Protestant Reformation]], the disastrous [[Thirty Years' War]], the [[Commercial Revolution]], the [[European colonization of the Americas]], and the [[Golden Age of Piracy]].
By the 16th century the economy under the [[Ming Dynasty]] was stimulated by trade with the Portuguese, the Spanish, and the Dutch, while Japan engaged in the [[Nanban trade]] after the arrival of the first European Portuguese during the [[Azuchi-Momoyama period]].
Other notable trends of the early modern period include the development of experimental science, accelerated travel due to improvements in mapping and ship design, increasingly rapid [[History of technology|technological progress]], [[secular]]ized civic politics, and the emergence of [[nation state]]s. Historians typically date the end of the early modern period when the [[French Revolution]] of the 1790s began the "late modern" period.<ref>[[Christopher Bayly|Christopher Alan Bayly]], ''The birth of the modern world, 1780–1914: global connections and comparisons'' (2004).</ref> {{TOC limit|limit=4}}
