[[History of Gibraltar|Historical]]
[[Politics of Gibraltar|Political]] |image =Gibraltar National Day 028 (9716508171) (2).jpg |caption = 2013 National Day celebrations held at [[Grand Casemates Square]] |official_name = |nickname = ''National Day
Gibraltar Day
Gib Day'' |observedby = [[Gibraltarian people]] |duration = 1 day |frequency = annual |scheduling = same day each year |date = 10 September |celebrations = [[Street party]], [[Verbena (fair)|Verbenas]], [[Street food]], [[Barbecue]]s, [[Competition]]s, [[Family reunion]]s, [[Foam party]], [[Concerts]], [[Fireworks]] |relatedto = [[Gibraltar Tercentenary Celebrations]] }} {{Culture of Gibraltar}} [[File:Flag of Gibraltar (9717050122).jpg|thumb|[[Flag of Gibraltar]] flying over the [[Foreign and Commonwealth Office]] in London during the 2013 National Day]] '''Gibraltar National Day''', celebrated annually on 10 September, is the official [[national day]] of the [[British overseas territories|British overseas territory]] of [[Gibraltar]]. The day commemorates [[Gibraltar sovereignty referendum, 1967|Gibraltar's first sovereignty referendum of 1967]], in which [[Gibraltarian people|Gibraltarian]] voters were asked whether they wished to either pass under [[Spain|Spanish]] [[sovereignty]], or remain under [[United Kingdom|British]] sovereignty, with institutions of [[self-governance|self-government]].[http://www.mod.uk/DefenceInternet/Templates/NewsArticle.aspx?NRMODE=Published&NRNODEGUID={57722B8A-113C-4A18-B7D3-350DD2B8A2CD}&NRORIGINALURL=%2FDefenceInternet%2FDefenceNews%2FHistoryAndHonour%2FGibraltarSoldiersCelebrateTheirNationalDayInIraq.htm&NRCACHEHINT=Guest Ministry of Defence – Gibraltar soldiers celebrate their National Day in Iraq] == History == In 1992, the [[Chief Minister of Gibraltar]] [[Joe Bossano]], travelled to the [[United Nations]] to argue for the right to [[self-determination]] inspiring the formation of the [[Self Determination for Gibraltar Group]] (SDGG) which was at the time headed by [[Dennis Matthews (politician)|Dennis Matthews]], a one-time active member of the [[Integration with Britain Party]] (IWBP). In order to generate popular support for self-determination they held the first National Day at [[John Mackintosh Square]] (the ''Piazza'') on 10 September 1992 to commemorate the 25th anniversary of the day the [[Gibraltar sovereignty referendum, 1967|1967 sovereignty referendum]] was held on. Coincidentally, the 10 September was also the day the [[Gibraltar Legislative Council]] became representative and responsible for internal affairs in 1964.{{Citation needed|date=February 2010}} The first National Day was so successful that the avalanche of people that spontaneously turned up could not fit into John Mackintosh Square. The [[Government of Gibraltar|Government]] then took the responsibility of providing some help organising the event, since it fostered the right to self-determination that the Gibraltarians had been demanding at the United Nations since 1963. Therefore, the Government declared the 10 September a [[public holiday]] and gave the SDGG a [[Grant (money)|grant]] for them to administer. In 1993 the venue was changed to the larger [[Grand Casemates Square]], until it was again changed in 1998 to the even larger [[Naval Ground]].{{Citation needed|date=February 2010}} === National identity === [[File:GIBRALTAR NATIONAL DAY (9716922401) (2).jpg|thumb|left|[[Gibraltarian people|Gibraltarians]] dress in their national colours of red and white on National Day.]] The [[Disputed status of Gibraltar|active opposition]] of the [[Spanish Government]] to self-determination combined with the negative posture of the [[Foreign and Commonwealth Office]], strengthened the resolution of the vast majority of the Gibraltarians to press ahead for their [[decolonisation]] by the year 2000 in accordance with the high principles of the Charter and the target date set by the United Nations to eradicate [[colonialism]].{{Citation needed|date=February 2010}} Instead, the [[Secretary of State for Foreign and Commonwealth Affairs|British Foreign Secretary]] [[Jack Straw]], proposed joint sovereignty with Spain, which further intensified the sense of [[national identity]] reinforced by the National Day. The 10th National Day, held in 2001 included a speech by [[William Serfaty]], the then leader of the SDGG, which stressed the themes of national identity, unity, resisting Spanish pressure and decolonisation.[http://www.self-determination.gi/speeches.htm SDGG Speech 2001] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20090912080130/http://www.self-determination.gi/speeches.htm |date=2009-09-12 }} === Changes to format === Subsequent National Days have comparatively been quieter affairs with fewer invited guests and shorter political speeches. In 2007 the running of the [[Demonstration (people)|political rally]] was taken over by the Government from the SDGG. In July 2008 the Government announced they would change the format of National Day to take effect the same year. The main change was their decision to no longer organise a political rally. The reason given was to emphasise civic celebration of Gibraltar rather than political revindication. Other changes included relocating the main event to the smaller John Mackintosh Square from Grand Casemates Square, appointing the [[Mayor of Gibraltar]] to conduct the main event rather than any political leader, the presentation of the [[Gibraltar Medallion of Honour]] and the reading of the Gibraltar National Day Declaration.[http://www.gibraltar.gov.gi/latest_news/press_releases/2008/181-2008.pdf Government of Gibraltar Press Release – Format changes to National Day] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20091113171242/http://www.gibraltar.gov.gi/latest_news/press_releases/2008/181-2008.pdf |date=2009-11-13 }} == Observances == [[File:Gibraltar National Day 026 (9719744436) (2).jpg|thumb|left|The [[balloon release|symbolic release]] of 30,000 red and white balloons from [[Grand Casemates Square]] on National Day 2013]] The official Gibraltar National Day events begin with a children’s [[costume party|fancy dress]] competition held at the lobby of the Parliament building in [[Main Street, Gibraltar|Main Street]] followed by a [[street party]] at John Mackintosh Square where food and drink stalls are set up providing [[Gibraltarian cuisine|Gibraltarian food]] such as [[calentita]]. Later a selected school choir sings songs with a Gibraltar theme, namely ''[[Llévame Donde Nací]]'' and ''[[Virgencita de Europa]]''. This is followed by the main event, the Mayor's recitation of the names of the recipients of the Gibraltar Medallion of Honour and the reading of the Gibraltar National Day Declaration from atop the City Hall's balcony. This was previously followed by the [[balloon release|traditional release]] from atop the Parliament building of 30,000 red and white [[balloon]]s, representing [[Demographics of Gibraltar|Gibraltar's population]], which had featured on this day since 1992. The balloon release tradition has been ended this year due to the threat that it poses to wildlife, marine wildlife in particular.{{cite news|title=Gibraltar ends annual balloon release on environmental grounds|url=https://www.theguardian.com/environment/2016/apr/07/gibraltar-ends-annual-balloon-release-on-environmental-grounds|accessdate=7 July 2016|agency=The Guardian|publisher=Guardian News and Media Limited or its affiliated companies|date=April 2016}} In the meantime, the school choir leads the general public in the singing of the [[Gibraltar Anthem]].[http://www.gibraltar.gov.gi/images/stories/PDF/pressoffice/pressreleases/2009/175-2009.pdf Government of Gibraltar – Gibraltar National Day events 2009]{{dead link|date=October 2017 |bot=InternetArchiveBot |fix-attempted=yes }} A [[funday]] for children featuring [[bouncy castle]]s and [[fairground ride]]s is then held at Grand Casemates Square. There is live music is played all afternoon at [[Governor’s Parade]] (the ''Piazzella'') and the [[Rock on the Rock Club]], all free of charge, as opposed to the [[Gibraltar Music Festival]] a paid event leading up to national day. Since 2007, there has been a [[verbena (fair)|verbena]] for the older members of the community. The day culminates with a half-hour-long synchronised [[fireworks]] display released from the [[Detached Mole, Gibraltar Harbour|Detached Mole]] in the [[Gibraltar Harbour]] at night followed by a [[rock concert]]. == Political rally == [[File:GIBRALTAR NATIONAL DAY 2013 - 238 (9716882215).jpg|thumb|[[Chief Minister of Gibraltar|Chief Minister]] [[Fabian Picardo]] delivering his speech during the 2013 National Day political rally]] In 2008, the Government announced that it would change the format of ''Gibraltar National Day'' celebrations with effect from this year. This followed the [[Gibraltar Constitution Order 2006|new Constitution]] in which Britain recognised Gibraltar's right to self-determination. The changes to the format were intended to emphasise Gibraltar's civic celebration rather than political revindication. There would be a gathering of the community at John Mackintosh Square for a collective celebratory event. The SDGG returned from its state of inactivity and organised a political rally at Grand Casemates Square featuring the leader of the SDGG, and those of the Opposition political parties: [[Gibraltar Liberal Party]] and the [[Progressive Democratic Party (Gibraltar)|Progressive Democratic Party]]. The event was scheduled to last a maximum of 30–45 minutes, allowing those participating to attend the main event of civic functions held at John Mackintosh Square. Speeches were short (around 5 minutes) kept to the leader of the SDGG and those of the other three parties. The event was well attended and seen as a success. The [[Gibraltar Social Democrats|GSD]] Government did not send a representative as they considered the main rally held at John Mackintosh Square to be the only ''official'' one.[http://www.gibraltar.gov.gi/latest_news/press_releases/2008/198-2008.pdf Government of Gibraltar Press Release – Government does not support the National Day political rally] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20091113171853/http://www.gibraltar.gov.gi/latest_news/press_releases/2008/198-2008.pdf |date=2009-11-13 }} == Gibraltar Medallion of Honour == {{Main|Gibraltar Medallion of Honour}} In July 2008, the [[Chief Minister of Gibraltar]], [[Peter Caruana]] announced that the Government would establish a civic award scheme, to be known as the [[Gibraltar Medallion of Honour]], which would be awarded by [[Gibraltar Parliament|Parliament]].[http://www.gibraltar.gi/locals/news.php?action=view_article&type=todays&article=3470 Gibraltar Medallion of Honour] The award is formally presented annually by the [[Mayor of Gibraltar]] prior to the release of the balloons on ''Gibraltar National Day''.[http://www.chronicle.gi/headlines_details.php?id=17178 Gibraltar Chronicle – 'We Are Gibraltar'] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20110927140859/http://www.chronicle.gi/headlines_details.php?id=17178 |date=2011-09-27 }} === 2009 recipients === The 2009 recipients of the Gibraltar Medallion of Honour were: * '''[[Jose Netto]]''' – for services to [[trade unionism]] and workers; * '''[[Adolfo Canepa]]''' – for [[public services]] and services to [[Politics of Gibraltar|politics]]; * '''[[Joseph Gaggero]]''' – for services to [[aviation]], [[shipping]], [[business]] and [[commerce]]; * '''[[Maurice Xiberras]]''' – for public services and services to politics. == Declaration == Since 2008, a Gibraltar National Day declaration is read by the Mayor of Gibraltar at a civic rally held at outside the [[Gibraltar City Hall|City Hall]]. It was first read out publicly by Mayor [[Solomon Levy]].[http://www.gibraltar.gov.gi/latest_news/press_releases/2008/181.1-2008.pdf Gibraltar National Day Declaration] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20091113171748/http://www.gibraltar.gov.gi/latest_news/press_releases/2008/181.1-2008.pdf |date=2009-11-13 }} == References == {{Reflist}} {{Commons category|Gibraltar National Day}} {{Gibraltar topics}} {{Public holidays in Europe}} [[Category:Annual events in Gibraltar]] [[Category:National days|Gibraltar]] [[Category:September observances]] [[Category:Gibraltarian society]]

[[File:Puppe und Ball Grönland 19Jh Linden-Museum.jpg|right|thumbnail|[[Greenlandic Inuit]] doll at the Stuttgart, Linden-Museum]] '''[[Inuit]] dolls''' are made out of [[soapstone]] and [[bone]], materials common to the people of northern [[Alaska]], [[Greenland]] and [[Northern Canada]]. Many are clothed with animal [[fur]] or skin. Their clothing articulates the traditional style of dress necessary to survive cold winters, wind, and snow. Dolls could have been gifts to young Inuit girls, to be used as teaching devices and passing down of culture.<ref>{{Cite journal|last=Issenman|first=Betty|date=1989-01-01|title=Review of Inuit Dolls: Reminders of a Heritage|jstor=40510866|journal=Arctic|volume=42|issue=4|pages=377–378|doi=10.14430/arctic1967}}</ref> With these dolls, young girls learn various skills necessary for their survival such as skin preparation, cutting & sewing, proper use of materials, designs and significance of symbols in their cultures. Inuit dolls were enjoyed by both young and old Inuit individuals and give an excellent insight into Inuit culture.<ref>{{Cite journal|last=Issenman|first=Betty|date=1989-01-01|title=Review of Inuit Dolls: Reminders of a Heritage|jstor=40510866|journal=Arctic|volume=42|issue=4|pages=377–378|doi=10.14430/arctic1967}}</ref><ref>{{Cite book|title=Inuit Dolls: Reminders of a Heritage|last=Strickler|first=Eva|publisher=Canadian Stage & Arts Publications Ltd.|year=1988|isbn=0919952380|location=|pages=|via=}}</ref>
==History== The earliest found [[dolls]] were made by Inuit living in [[Brooman Point Village]], [[Bathurst Island (Nunavut)|Bathurst Island]] over two thousand years ago. Since the migration of humans over the [[Beringia|land bridge]] in the [[Bering Strait]], these dolls were common in [[Inuit culture]]. While the history of creating these dolls are unknown, the tradition may have started over 1,000 years ago.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.historymuseum.ca/cmc/exhibitions/hist/dolls/doinu01e.shtml|title=Civilization.ca - Timeless Treasures - Inuit Dolls from Prehistory to Today|website=www.historymuseum.ca|access-date=2016-08-12}}</ref> There are at least two different types of Inuit dolls from the [[Canadians|Canadian]] region, Play dolls and Collector's Dolls.<ref>{{Cite journal|last=Issenman|first=Betty|date=1989-01-01|title=Review of Inuit Dolls: Reminders of a Heritage|jstor=40510866|journal=Arctic|volume=42|issue=4|pages=377–378|doi=10.14430/arctic1967}}</ref>
===Play Dolls===
At the young age of ten, Inuit girls are taught by their mothers how the clothe a family.<ref>{{Cite journal|last=Issenman|first=Betty|date=1989-01-01|title=Review of Inuit Dolls: Reminders of a Heritage|jstor=40510866|journal=Arctic|volume=42|issue=4|pages=377–378|doi=10.14430/arctic1967}}</ref> This is mainly taught by learning to sew making their own dolls with removable clothing.<ref>{{Cite news|url=|title=Inuit Packing Dolls exhibit shares culture|last=Miller|first=Heather Andrews|date=November 1, 2010|work=|newspaper=Alberta Sweetgrass|access-date=|via=ProQuest}}</ref> They learn about the roles of wives and mothers by playing with these dolls. Once Inuit people moved to camps and settlements, young girls started going to school and started learning different kinds of lessons and schools. This change in education for young Inuit girls, the play dolls began disappearing. The last [[generation]] to grow up with the play dolls were girls from the early 1950s.<ref>{{Cite journal|last=Issenman|first=Betty|date=1989-01-01|title=Review of Inuit Dolls: Reminders of a Heritage|jstor=40510866|journal=Arctic|volume=42|issue=4|pages=377–378|doi=10.14430/arctic1967}}</ref><ref>{{Cite book|title=Inuit Dolls: Reminders of a Heritage|last=Strickler|first=Eva|publisher=Canadian Stage & Arts Publications Ltd.|year=1988|isbn=0919952380|location=|pages=|via=}}</ref>
=== Collector's Dolls ===
These dolls were typically made by Inuit people for people in the south. Some are owned by museums and others are owned by private collectors and institutions. The collector’s dolls were divided into four categories: dolls dressed in traditional fur garments, wearing fabric garments, made by elders from [[Taloyoak|Spence Bay]], and lastly made by the best dollmakers in [[Taloyoak|Spence Bay]].<ref>{{Cite journal|last=Issenman|first=Betty|date=1989-01-01|title=Review of Inuit Dolls: Reminders of a Heritage|jstor=40510866|journal=Arctic|volume=42|issue=4|pages=377–378|doi=10.14430/arctic1967}}</ref><ref>{{Cite book|title=Inuit Dolls: Reminders of a Heritage|last=Strickler|first=Eva|publisher=Canadian Stage & Arts Publications Ltd.|year=1988|isbn=0919952380|location=|pages=|via=}}</ref>
The dolls made by elders are full of energy and imagination. They are sculptures made from fur and fabric. Some are reminders of what the culture used to be like and others are just fantasy of the imagination the dollmaker. The dolls made by Spence Bay’s best dollmakers are full of intense artistry. Dolls could have been made from [[caribou]] antler to create a certain texture. Dollmakers could have also used [[soapstone]] to create eyes and generate certain emotions and feelings.<ref>{{Cite journal|last=Issenman|first=Betty|date=1989-01-01|title=Review of Inuit Dolls: Reminders of a Heritage|jstor=40510866|journal=Arctic|volume=42|issue=4|pages=377–378|doi=10.14430/arctic1967}}</ref> Dollmakers have also made dolls specifically called Packing Dolls that generally wear an [[amauti]]. Packing dolls refer to dolls that have a [[parka]] that is designed with a baby pouch tailored as part of the mother’s clothing.<ref>{{Cite news|url=|title=Inuit Packing Dolls exhibit shares culture|last=Miller|first=Heather Andrews|date=November 1, 2010|work=|newspaper=Alberta Sweetgrass|access-date=|via=}}</ref>
==See also== * [[Yup'ik doll]]

Alaska State Council of the Arts, 1982. *Larson, Jack Lenor. ''Folk Art from the Global Village''. Santa Fe, NM: Museum of New Mexico Press, 1995.

{{native name|fa|عرب‌های ايران}} | image = | flag = | population = ~1.5 million[https://www.cia.gov/library/publications/the-world-factbook/geos/ir.html CIA World Factbook] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20120203093100/https://www.cia.gov/library/publications/the-world-factbook/geos/ir.html |date=2012-02-03 }}| popplace = [[Khuzestan Province|Khuzestan]], [[Khorasan Province|Khorasan]], [[Hormozgan Province|Hormozgan]], [[Bushehr Province|Bushehr]], [[Qom Province|Qom]] | langs = [[Arabic language|Arabic]] ([[Khuzestani Arabic]], [[Khorasani Arabic]]), [[Persian language|Persian]] | rels = [[Twelver]] [[Shi'a Islam]](great majority), [[Sunni Islam]] (minority)Nikki R. Keddie, "Iran and the Muslim World: Resistance and Revolution", New York University Press, 1995 (3/5/09). pp. 12–13: "Many writings state that the Arabs are Sunni, but the only bases for this assertion seem to be that most Arabs in the world are Sunni, that some Arabs in Khuzestan rarely are Sunni, and the Shi’a Arabs follow some customs that Persians associate with Sunnism. In the absence of scholarly work or census surveys, it is impossible to estimate the percentages of Shi’as and Sunnis among the Arabs, but the evidence suggests that the great majority of Iranian Arabs are Shi’ite. First, the Arabs border on a part of Iraq that is, and has long been, almost entirely Shi’ite, and it would be surprising to find a Sunni pocket in such an area, especially since, second, they live in the Shi'ite state of Iran." | related = [[Arabs]] ([[Ahwazi Arabs]], [[Khamseh Arabs]], [[Marsh Arabs]], [[Arabs in Khorasan]]), [[Iraqi people|Iraqis]], [[Bahrani people|Bahranis]], [[Mandaeism|Mandaeans]] }} [[File:Ethnicities and religions in Iran.png|thumb|right|Iran's ethnoreligious distribution]] '''Iranian Arabs''' ({{lang-ar|عرب إيران}} ''ʿArab Īrān''; {{lang-fa|عرب‌های ايران}} ''Arabhāye Irān'') refers to the citizens or residents of [[Iran]] who are ethnically [[Arab]]. Iranian Arabs form around 2% of Iran's population which is around 1.5 million people. ==Overview== The Arab presence in Iran did not begin with the [[Arab conquest of Persia]] in 633 AD. For centuries, Iranian rulers had maintained contacts with Arabs outside their borders, dealt with Arab subjects and client states (such as those of [[Iraq]] and [[Yemen]]), and settled Arab tribesmen in various parts of the Iranian plateau. It follows that the "Arab" conquests and settlements were by no means the exclusive work of Arabs from the [[Hejaz]] and the tribesmen of inner Arabia. The Arab expedition to Iran began before the Muslim conquests and continued as a result of the joint exertions of the civilized Arabs (ahl al-madar) as well as the desert Arabs (ahl al-wabar).{{cite encyclopedia |last=Daniel |first=E. L. | title= Arab settlements in Iran | encyclopedia=Encyclopædia Iranica | accessdate=2011-04-09|url=http://www.iranicaonline.org/articles/arab-iii}} According to the [[Minorities at Risk]] Project 2001, about 40% of Arabs are unskilled workers living in urban areas. The Arabs in the rural areas are primarily farmers and fishermen. The Arabs living along the Persian Gulf coastal plains are mostly pastoral nomads. Tribal loyalties are strong among rural Arabs, but also have an influence in urban areas. These affect Arab socialisation and politicisation.[http://www.homeoffice.gov.uk/rds/pdfs05/iran_081205.doc Iran Overview from [[British Home Office]]] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20090718101816/http://www.homeoffice.gov.uk/rds/pdfs05/iran_081205.doc |date=2009-07-18 }} [[Payame Noor University]], which has 229 campuses throughout the country, in 2008 declared that Arabic will be the "second language" of the university, and that all its services will be offered in [[Arabic language|Arabic]], concurrent with [[Persian language|Persian]].[http://radiozamaaneh.com/news/2008/03/post_4081.html رادیو زمانه | خبر اول | ایران | عربی دومین زبان دانشگاه پیام نور شد] ==History== [[Shapur II|Shapur II the Great]] (309–379 A.D.) of the [[Sassanid Empire]], after a [[punitive expedition]] across the Persian Gulf early in his reign, transplanted several clans of the [[Taghleb]] to Dārzīn (Daharzīn) near [[Bam, Iran|Bam]], several clans of the [[Abd al-Qays]] and [[Tamīm]] to Haǰar (the Kūh-e Hazār region) southeast of [[Kermān]], several clans of the [[Banu Bakr|Bakr ben Wāʾel]] to Kermān, and several clans of the [[Hanzala]] to Tavvaz, near present-day [[Dalaki|Dālakī]] in [[Fārs]].{{cite encyclopedia |last=Oberling and Hourcade |first=P.and B. | title= Arab tribes of Iran | encyclopedia=Encyclopædia Iranica | accessdate=2011-04-09|url=http://www.iranicaonline.org/articles/arab-iv}} Although after the Arab conquest of the Sassanid Persian empire in the 7th century, many Arab tribes settled in different parts of Iran, it is the Arab tribes of [[Khuzestan province|Khuzestan]] that have retained their identity in language, culture, and Shia Islam to the present day. But ethno-linguistic characteristics of the region must be studied against the long and turbulent history of the province, with its own local language ''khuzi'', which may have been of [[Elamite]] origin and which gradually disappeared in the early medieval period. The immigration of Arab tribes from outside the province was also a long-term process. There was a great influx of Arab-speaking immigrants into the province from the 16th to the 19th century, including the migration of the [[Banu Kaab]] and [[Banu Lam]]. There were attempts by the Iraqi regime during the [[Iran–Iraq War]] (1980–88) to generate Arab nationalism in the area but without any palpable success. {{cite web | last = FRYE | first = Richard Nelson | authorlink =Richard Nelson Frye | coauthors = | title = PEOPLES OF IRAN | work = | publisher = [[Encyclopaedia Iranica]] | date =May 2, 2006 | url = http://www.iranicaonline.org/articles/iran-v1-peoples-survey | doi = | accessdate = 2008-12-14}} ===Genetics=== Sampling [[Y-Chromosome|NRY]] diversity, it was found that the [[Human Y-chromosome DNA haplogroup|Y-DNA]] [[Haplogroup F-M89 (Y-DNA)|haplogroups F]] and [[Haplogroup J-M172 (Y-DNA)|J2]] are carried at very high frequency among the Iranian Arabs—those two markers alone accounting for over half of Iranian Arab haplogroups.Nasidze, I., Quinque, D., Rahmani, M., Alemohamad, S. A. and Stoneking, M. (2008), "Close Genetic Relationship Between Semitic-speaking and Indo-European-speaking Groups in Iran." ''Annals of Human Genetics'', 72: 241–252. This high ratio of [[Haplogroup F-M89 (Y-DNA)|haplogroup F]], in particular, relates them, in a genetic sense, to peoples of the [[Eastern Mediterranean]] and of the [[Barbary Coast]], while an elevated frequency of haplogroup J-M172 is typical of [[Levant|Near Eastern]] peoples and reflective of the genetic legacy of early agriculturalists in, and their [[Demic diffusion|diffusion]] from, the Neolithic Near East ''c''. 8000–4000 BCE. Semino O, Passarino G, Oefner P J, Lin A A, Arbuzova S, Beckman L E, de Benedictis G, Francalacci P, Kouvatsi A, Limborska S, et al. (2000) Science 290:1155–1159 Underhill P A, Passarino G, Lin A A, Shen P, Foley R A, Mirazon-Lahr M, Oefner P J, Cavalli-Sforza L L (2001) Ann Hum Genet 65:43–62R. Spencer Wells et al., "The Eurasian Heartland: A continental perspective on Y-chromosome diversity," Proceedings of the National Academy of Sciences of the United States of America (August 28, 2001 [[Haplogroup R-M420 (Y-DNA)|Haplogroup R1a1]], and [[Haplogroup R-M173 (Y-DNA)|R1]], typical of [[Indo-Iranians|Indo-Iranian]] groups, is also important, occurring in over 11% of the sample; [[Haplogroup G-M201 (Y-DNA)|haplogroup G]] is present in over 5%. ==Regional groups== [[File:Map of Arabian-inhabited provinces of Iran, according to a poll in 2010.PNG|thumb|right|Provinces of Iran based on the population of Arabs, according to the survey carried out by Ministry of Culture, 2010.]] ===Khuzestan=== {{Main|Ahwazi Arabs}} Most Iranian Arabs in [[Khūzestān Province]] are [[bilingual]], speaking [[Arabic language|Arabic]] as their mother tongue, and [[Persian language|Persian]] as a second language. The [[varieties of Arabic|variety of Arabic]] spoken in the province is [[Khuzestani Arabic]], which is a [[Iraqi Arabic|Mesopotamian]] dialect shared by Arabs across the border in [[Iraq]]. It can be easily understood by other Arabic-speakers. From the immigrant Arab tribes of Khuzestan (from the present-day Iraq), the [[Banu Kaab]] at Dawraq (the later Fallāhīya and the present-day [[Shadegan]]) and the [[Musha'sha'iyyah|Mawlāʾī]] at [[Hoveyzeh]] can be mentioned.{{cite web|last=Towfīq|first=F|title=ʿAŠĀYER "tribes" in Iran|url=http://www.iranicaonline.org/articles/asayer-tribes|work=Encyclopædia Iranica.|accessdate=14 April 2012}} The well-known [[Bani Turuf]] tribe is settled in the [[Dasht-e Azadegan County|Dasht e Azadegan]] (formerly Dasht-e Mīshān) around the town of Hūzagān (formerly [[Hoveyzeh]]), and consists of seven tribes, the Sovārī, Marzaā, Shorfa, Banī Sāleh, Marvān, Qāṭeʿ, and Sayyed Nemat. North of the lands of the ʿAnāfeja of the Āl Katīr, in the area called Mīānāb, between the Kārūn and [[Karkheh River]]s, dwell several Arab tribes, of which the best known are the Kaab (probably an offshoot of the Banī Kaʿb of southern Khuzestan), the ʿAbd al khānī, the Mazraa, the Al Bū Rāwīya, and the Sādāt. These tribes gradually immigrated into Iran during and after the early years of the Qajar period. ===Fars=== {{Main|Khamseh Arabs}} [[Khamseh Arabs|Khamseh Arab]] nomads live in eastern [[Fars Province]] (From Lar and close surrounding areas to Khorrambid and Bavanat). Arabs that live in eastern Fars Province and Hormozgan mostly belong to the tribes of [[Banu Tamim]], [[Banu Kaab]] and [[Banu Hammed]]. ===Khorasan=== {{Main|Arabs in Khorasan}} Most [[Arabs in Khorasan|Khorasani-Arabs]] belong to the tribes of [[Sheyban]]i, [[Zangooyi]], [[Mishmast]], [[Khozaima]] and [[Azdi]]. [[Khorasan Province|Khorasan]] Arabs are Persian speakers and only a few speak Arabic as their mother tongue. Khorasani-Arabs in the cities [[Birjand]], [[Mashhad]] and [[Nishapur]] are a big ethnic group.History of the Arabs. Filip Hetti 1990 ==Demographics== Elton Daniel in ''The History of Iran'' (Greenwood Press, 2001), states that the Arabs of Iran ''"are concentrated in the province of Khuzistan and number about half a million"''.The History of Iran (Greenwood Press, 2001), (pg. 14) The ''Historical Dictionary of Iran'' puts the number at 1 million.Lorentz, J. (1995) p.172 Iranian Arabs form 2% of Iran's population. ==See also== *[[List of Iranian Arabs]] *[[Lakhmids]] *[[Alavids]] *[[Iraqis in Iran]] *[[Lebanese people in Iran]] *[[Moaved]] *[[Shia Muslims in the Arab world]] *[[Abyssinian–Persian wars]] *[[Arab diaspora]] ==References== {{Reflist}} ==External links== *{{cite encyclopedia |last=Daniel |first=E. L. | title= Arab settlements in Iran | encyclopedia=Encyclopædia Iranica | accessdate=2011-04-09|url=http://www.iranicaonline.org/articles/arab-iii}} *{{cite encyclopedia |last=Oberling and Hourcade |first=P.and B. | title= Arab tribes of Iran | encyclopedia=Encyclopædia Iranica | accessdate=2011-04-09|url=http://www.iranicaonline.org/articles/arab-iv}} * [https://www.academia.edu/2609751/George_Grigore._Le_systeme_consonantique_de_larabe_parle_a_Khorramshahr_Iran_Romano-Arabica_VIII-XI._Bucarest_Editura_Universitatii_din_Bucuresti_2011_93-102 About Spoken Arabic of Khoramshahr] {{Ethnic groups in Iran}} {{Semitic topics}} {{Arab diaspora}} {{UNPO}} [[Category:Ethnic groups in Iran|Arabs]] [[Category:Arab diaspora in Asia]] [[Category:Semitic-speaking peoples]] [[Category:Iranian Arab people| ]] [[Category:Khuzestan Province]]

The '''Irish Exhibition of Living Art''' ('''IELA''') was a yearly exhibition of Irish abstract expressionism and avant-garde Irish art that was started in 1943 by [[Mainie Jellett]].<ref name=NYTIMES>{{cite news|last=O'Doherty|first=Brian|title=In Dublin: Pubs, Poets, Painters-Alive, Alive-O|url=http://search.proquest.com/docview/116068288/|accessdate=19 Feb 2015|newspaper=New York Times|date=26 Aug 1962}}</ref>
==Background==
===World War II Ireland=== During World War II, Ireland remained mostly uninvolved in the war that swept through most the rest of Europe, known only as "the Emergency" in Ireland.<ref name=ThatIsOnlyWar>{{cite news|last=Richardson|first=Caleb|title=That is only war: Irish writers and the emergency|journal=UMI Dissertations Publishing|year=2006|pages=2–4|url=http://search.proquest.com/docview/304978789}}</ref> Taking a "neutral" stance in the war, Ireland did not engage directly in the war on either side and declined to make any kind of established allegiance to the Axis or Allied powers. As a result, Ireland experienced a period of isolation from the rest of the Western world, with few Irishmen travelling abroad and few foreigners travelling to Ireland. This period of isolation set in motion a period of criticism and questioning of the fledgling country's national identity and ideals, with various factions unhappy with the status quo in the island nation. Some of the primary concerns for those unsatisfied with the state of the Ireland at the time included a government unconcerned with the republican ideals the nation was created with, widespread poverty in Ireland, and a general inability for the nation to be a major player on the world stage capable of defending itself. With these concerns and isolation, the Irish people sought to question the direction Ireland was headed in. And in this war period and the time that immediately followed, Ireland and its artists also sought to question what constituted "Irish art" and how that would impact Irish identity.<ref name=ThatIsOnlyWar />
===Art In Ireland=== Art in Ireland during the 1930s and 1940s still primarily consisted of traditional representational art. Championed by the Royal Hibernian Academy and the National College of Art, this traditionalist art remained the favored style of visual artistic creation following the Emergency period.{{Citation needed|reason=Reliable source needed for the this sentence and the previous one|date=April 2015}} Many Irish artists rejected the established institutions and sought philosophical inspiration from other fields, particularly that of literature.<ref name=TheEmergency /> Although it was not until the late 1930s that the character of Irish art was to be seriously challenged as Irish artists began seeking an Irish artistic identity. With artists like Mainie Jellett leading the way, artists of Ireland, who more frequently received no formal education due to some of the institutions more restrictive policies, found an outlet to challenge the traditionalist movements in Ireland through organizations like the IELA.<ref name=TheEmergency>{{cite news|last=Kennedy|first=Roisin|title=The emergency: a turning point for Irish art?|journal=Circa|year=2000|pages=1–2|url=http://search.proquest.com/docview/1320756901}}</ref>
Prior to the opening of the IELA, only one major exhibition took place each year in Dublin, which was the Annual Exhibition of the Royal Hibernian Academy. The RHA, and other major art institutions in Ireland at this time, supported art that accurately portrayed reality.<ref name=LivingArt>{{cite news|last=Coleman|first=John|title=A Painter of Living Art: Jack P. Hanlon 1913-1968|journal=|year=1988|pages=222|doi=10.2307/20492069}}</ref> And while the established art forums favored traditional representational art, there was some push back from groups of artists in favor of modernist art. One of the most well-known of these prior to the IELA was known as the [[White Stag Group]] which was formed in the late 1930s. The White Stag Group, formed by Kenneth Hall and Basil Rakoczi, had middle-class English roots that eventually took hold in Dublin and the rest of Ireland. It wasn't until organizations like the IELA and White Stag Group came about that non-traditional Irish art had a means of being displayed in a way that was accessible and popular.<ref name=Stag>{{cite book|last=Keown, Edwina|first=and Carol Taaffe|title=Irish Modernism|publisher=Peter Lang AG, International Publishers|pages=181–182|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=iu5qMGrr3QcC&printsec=frontcover#v=onepage&q&f=false}}</ref>
==History of the IELA== The IELA was formed in 1943 after a group of middle-class artists in Ireland sought to oppose the traditional hegemony created by the [[Royal Hibernian Academy]] (RHA) and the National College of Art in Ireland. Artists in this group included [[Norah McGuinness]], [[Mainie Jellett]], [[Evie Hone]], Fr. [[Jack Hanlon (Priest and Painter)|Jack Hanlon]] and [[Louis le Brocquy]], among others.<ref name=IELAbio>{{cite web|url=http://www.artbiogs.co.uk/2/societies/irish-exhibition-living-art|title=Irish Exhibition of Living Art|work=British and Irish Artists of the 20th Century|publisher=Artist Biographies|accessdate=19 Feb 2014|ref=none}}</ref> While not all of them subscribed completely to the modernism of the rest of western Europe and the United States, these artists did seek to stray off the path established by Irish art institutions. Many artists that founded the IELA were influenced by the dissenting Impressionist art circles in Paris who broke away from the French Academy. Even though they understood this may cause friction with established institutions in Ireland, many of the founders saw the French as an example to be followed. However, many artists managed to form a delicate balance, seeing as artists who displayed their work in the IELA also displayed pieces through the other traditional institutions such as the RHA. Nonetheless, the IELA's main goal was to provide a forum for artists who sought to reshape the Irish artistic landscape and provided them the means through which to do that.<ref name=LivingArt />
The beginnings of the IELA can be traced to an open criticism of the RHA by Jellett which ultimately led to other modernist artists like le Brocquy having their works rejected for exhibitions hosted annually by the RHA. In response to this, Jellett and other modernist artists established the IELA to create a forum to display the work of artists regardless of what school or style they subscribed to. Reviews of the IELA's first show in 1943 indicated the division in the art world over artistic identity and creativity.<ref name=IELAhist>{{cite web|url=http://www.visual-arts-cork.com/irish-exhibition-of-living-art.htm|title=Irish Exhibition of Living Art (IELA) (1943-1980s)|work=Irish Exhibition of Living Art|publisher=History and Foundation of the IELA|accessdate=19 Feb 2014|ref=none}}</ref> In some instances, this division was deeply entrenched, especially in the National College of Art, which was opposed to modernist movements for some time. However, this opposition was not felt as strongly in every established institution in the country. Even though steadfastness for traditional art was common, much of the art world in Ireland remained fairly well connected and eased their opposition to the tide of modernism coming from continent-inspired artists. Both the modernist and traditionalist camps had their work displayed by the same institutions in some instances. Ultimately, this coexistence allowed for institutions like IELA to be friendly with organizations such as the RHA, without which the IELA would have no traction in the Dublin art world.<ref name=IELAhist />
Not only did the IELA seek to break from the traditional norms of Irish art, it was displayed some progressive trends for its time, whether intentionally or otherwise. For example, women artists played a critical role in the formation and establishment of the IELA. The first two presidents of the Exhibition, Mainie Jellett and Norah McGuinness, were women who held the position during the formative years of the Exhibition. Jellett, who served as the president before her death in 1944, played a key role in its formation, and McGuinness, who served for over 20 years after its foundation, played a critical role in maintaining the direction that the IELA stood for.<ref name=WomenArtists>{{cite news|last=Mayes, Elizabeth, Jeni Rogers, Wanda Ryan-Smolin|title=Irish Women Artists: From the 18th Century to the Present Day|journal=|year=1990|pages=45–49|jstor=1358389}}</ref> In the decades following its conception, the IELA became a fixture in the Irish art world. However, while they did become established, they did not allow themselves to lose sight of the founding principles of the institution. True to the spirit of the IELA, the original management stepped down and handed off the Exhibition to a younger generation of artists in 1972. The IELA continued to influence young artists well into the future.<ref name=HistofIreland>{{cite book|last=Hill|first=J. R.|title=A New History of Ireland, Volume VII: Medieval Ireland 1921-1984|publisher=Oxford University Press|pages=606–607|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=PfFXarIhGqEC&pg=PT84&lpg=PT84&dq=A+New+History+of+Ireland,+Volume+VII&source=bl&ots=86rx_eRc1m&sig=6b7_13lLlYMHNVISv3W-mEt_Ows&hl=en&sa=X&ei=Os0qVcq4AoewggTgvYG4BQ&ved=0CEEQ6AEwBg#v=onepage&q=%22Irish%20Exhibition%20of%20Living%20Art%22&f=false}}</ref>
To this day, the IELA remains a showcase for contemporary art and has since expanded to include other art forms such as performance, video, and installation art.<ref name=IELAhist /> The IELA has played an enormous role in developing the Irish art scene and providing an outlet through which the artists of Ireland can display their works while also challenging the norm in Irish art, even being called a part of the "birth of Modernism in the visual arts in Ireland."<ref name=IrishTimes>{{cite news|last=Lilliput|first=Dorothy|title=Knowing the difference Brian Kennedy welcomes a 'splendid' history of Irish modern art|url=http://www.lexisnexis.com/hottopics/lnacademic/?verb=sr&csi=142626&sr=HLEAD(Knowing%20the%20difference%20Brian%20Kennedy%20welcomes%20a%20%60splendid%20history%20of%20Irish%20modern%20art)%20and%20date%20is%201998|accessdate=19 Feb 2015|newspaper=The Irish Times|date=10 Jan 1998}}</ref> The Exhibition even expanded to include postmodernist art to expose both the public and artists alike to new developing styles.<ref name=IELAhist />

{{Infobox officeholder
|name = James Onanefe Ibori |order = 2nd [[Governor of Delta State]] |image = |deputy = Benjamin Elue |predecessor = [[Walter Feghabo]] |successor = [[Emmanuel Uduaghan]] |birth_date = {{birth date and age|1959|08|04|df=7}} |birth_place = [[Oghara]], [[Delta State]], [[Nigeria]] |death_date = |death_place = |alma_mater = [[University of Benin (Nigeria)|University of Benin]], [[Nigeria]] |term_start = 29 May 1999 |term_end = 29 May 2007 }}
'''James Onanefe Ibori''' (born 4 August 1959) is a Nigerian politician who was [[List of Governors of Delta State|Governor]] of [[Delta State]] in [[Nigeria]] from 29 May 1999 to 29 May 2007. An ethnic [[Urhobo People|Urhobo]] by descent, Ibori is a member of the [[People's Democratic Party (Nigeria)|People's Democratic Party]] (PDP). He is an influential leader in the [[Niger Delta]] region and a national figure in Nigeria.
==Early life== Born to the family of late Chief Ukavbe Ibori and Mrs. Comfort Oji Ibori of Otefe in [[Oghara]] clan, [[Ethiope West]] Local Government Area of [[Delta State]], he attended Baptist High School, Oghareki, now Oghareki Grammar School, before proceeding to the [[University of Benin (Nigeria)|University of Benin]] where he obtained a [[Bachelor of Science]] degree in [[Economics]] and [[Statistics]].<ref>{{Citation | title = Constitution Amendment Must Allow Popular Will, Says Eyinne | newspaper = ''[[AllAfrica.com]]'' | publisher = AllAfrica Global Media | date = 24 February 2006 | url = http://allafrica.com/stories/200602240267.html | accessdate =}}</ref> Ibori moved to [[London]], [[England]] in the 1980s where he married his wife, Theresa. He worked as a cashier at [[Wickes]] [[DIY]] store in [[Ruislip]], [[Middlesex]]. In 1990, the couple were arrested for theft from the store, and fined £300. In 1991, he was convicted of handling a stolen credit card, and fined £100.<ref>{{cite news| url=http://www.dailymail.co.uk/news/article-2130593/James-Ibori-Wickes-cashier-governor-oil-rich-Nigerian-state-scam.html#ixzz1sJzvJVAD | location=London | work=Daily Mail | first=Simon | last=Tomlinson | title=Former Wickes cashier who became governor of oil-rich Nigerian state jailed for 13 years as judge says £50m fraud figure may be 'ludicrously low' | date=16 April 2012}}</ref>
Returning to Nigeria, between 1994 and 1997 he served as a consultant to the Federal Government of President [[Sani Abacha]], in the areas of public policy formulation and implementation. In 1999, Ibori took out a mortgage on a property in [[Abbey Road]], London. To mask his previous convictions in the UK, he obtained a false birth certificate and then passport, medically impossible as it was dated a month after his elder sisters birthdate.<ref name=BBC17184075>{{cite news| url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/world-africa-17184075 | work=BBC News | title=James Ibori: How a thief almost became Nigeria's president | date=27 February 2012}}</ref>
==Political career== Ibori's political career began in 1990 when he joined the [[National Republican Convention]] (NRC). In 1991, he was nominated to contest for the Federal House of Representatives seat, to represent Ethiope Federal Constituency. He lost the election to the Social Democratic Party (SDP) candidate.
When the Sani Abacha Transition Programme kicked off, he joined the [[Grassroots Democratic Movement]] (GDM). The GDM clinched a good number of local, state and federal positions, including one of the three senatorial seats in the state. The transition programme was abruptly terminated with the death of Abacha. Ibori then with the leaders of other defunct political groups in Delta State, formed the Delta National Congress (DNC).
The DNC later merged with many others of like ideas to birth the [[People's Democratic Party (Nigeria)|Peoples Democratic Party]] (PDP). It was on the platform of the PDP that he contested and won the January 9, 1999 Delta State Gubernatorial Election.
Proposed as governor of Delta State, under Nigerian law Ibori had to swear that he had no previous convictions. Using the false birth certificate and passport that he had used for the mortgage application in London, he passed the tests falsely, and was elected to become the governor from 1999.<ref name=BBC17184075/> In 2003, he was re-elected as governor for another four-year term.
At the PDP's ruling party's pre-election convention in 2006, Ibori was on hand to lift up the hand of the victorious [[Umaru Yar'Adua]]. After Yar'Adua was selected as their presidential candidate, Ibori was accused of bank-rolling Yar'Adua's 2007 campaign, and promised a Vice-Presidential position in return. But after Yar'Adua died in office, Vice-President [[Goodluck Jonathan]] succeeded Yar'Adua, an avowed political opponent of Ibori.<ref name=BBC17184075/>
==Corruption charges==
===United Kingdom charges=== Ibori's corruption charges started with filling of petitions by his kinsmen under the auspices of Delta State Elders and Stateholders Forum influenced by the foremost Ijaw leader, [[Chief E. K. Clark]], OFR, CON who was also the former Minister of Information. The petition was sent to [[Nuhu Ribadu]],the head of Nigeria's financial crimes agencies who initially failed to act on the petition which made the Forum, who, with other activists, revealed Ibori's crimes and made spirited efforts to bring Ibori and EFCC before court to compel Ibori's prosecution with the aid of their lawyer Kayode Ajulo.
In 2007, the [[Metropolitan Police]] raided the London offices of lawyer Bhadresh Gohil. Hidden in a wall behind a fireplace, they found computer [[hard drive]]s containing details of a myriad off-shore companies, run for Ibori by Gohil, fiduciary agent Daniel Benedict McCann, and corporate financier Lambertus De Boer. All of these men were later jailed for a total of 30 years.<ref>{{cite news| url=http://www.dailymail.co.uk/news/article-2130593/James-Ibori-Wickes-cashier-governor-oil-rich-Nigerian-state-scam.html#ixzz1sLApsWeM | location=London | work=Daily Mail | first=Simon | last=Tomlinson | title=Former Wickes cashier who became governor of oil-rich Nigerian state jailed for 13 years as judge says £50m fraud figure may be 'ludicrously low' | date=16 April 2012}}</ref>
As a result of these corruption allegations, the United Kingdom courts froze Ibori's assets there, valued at about £17 million ($35 million), in early August 2007.<ref>{{cite news |first= Estelle |last=Shirbon |title=Britain freezes assets of former governor |url=http://www.int.iol.co.za/index.php?set_id=1&click_id=86&art_id=nw20070806134708872C996099 |work=Reuters (IOL) |publisher= Independent News & Media|date=2007-08-06 |accessdate=2007-12-17 }}</ref> His wife, Nkoyo, was arrested at [[Heathrow Airport]] in London on 1 November 2007, in connection with the probe of the assets of her husband, particularly in the United Kingdom.<ref>{{cite news |title= Airport 'arrest' for Nigeria wife |url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/1/hi/world/africa/7074573.stm |work=[[BBC News]] |publisher= BBC|date=2007-11-02 |accessdate=2007-12-17 }}</ref> She was released after being questioned. In an exclusive interview with [[CNN]], Ibori denied allegations against him claiming they were politically motivated. He accused [[Nuhu Ribadu]] and the UK Courts of playing politics.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://edition.cnn.com/video/#/video/world/2010/03/16/purefoy.nigeria.corruption.cnn?iref=allsearch |title=Breaking News Videos, Story Video and Show Clips - CNN.com |publisher=Edition.cnn.com |date= |accessdate=2015-07-29}}</ref>
===First set of Nigerian charges=== On December 12, 2007, Ibori was arrested by the Economic and Financial Crimes Commission (EFCC) at the Kwara State Lodge in Asokoro, Abuja.<ref>{{cite news |title= Ige, Ise-Oluwa; Emmanuel Ulayi (2007-12-12). "Ibori arrested, faces 103-count charge". Vanguard Online (Vanguard Media). |url=http://www.vanguardngr.com/index.php?option=com_content&task=view&id=3020&Itemid=57 |work=[[Vanguard News]] |publisher= [[Vanguard Media]]|date=2007-11-02 |accessdate=2007-12-17 }}</ref> The charges he faces include theft of public funds, abuse of office, and [[money laundering]]. These corruption charges brought against Ibori by the government of former President Obasanjo are among many begun by anticorruption czar [[Nuhu Ribadu]] against former officials of the Peoples Democratic Party PDP. Ribadu additionally alleged that Ibori attempted to bribe him to drop the charges with a cash gift of $15 million, which Ribadu immediately lodged in the Central Bank of Nigeria CBN. The cash remains in the CBN as an exhibit.<ref>{{cite web |url= http://saharareporters.com/index.php?option=com_content&view=article&id=4056:iboris-goose-and-ribadus-trumpet&catid=81:external-contrib&Itemid=300|title=Ibori’s Goose and Ribadu’s Trumpet|publisher=Saharareporters.com|accessdate=2015-07-29}}</ref>
On December 17, 2009, A Federal High Court sitting in Asaba, Delta State, discharged and acquitted Ibori of all 170 charges of corruption brought against him by EFCC.<ref>[http://234next.com/csp/cms/sites/Next/News/National/5498438-146/story.csp] {{webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20100820121243/http://234next.com/csp/cms/sites/Next/News/National/5498438-146/story.csp |date=August 20, 2010 }}</ref> The EFCC filed a notice of appeal against the December 17, 2009 judgement, and has begun a new round of investigations on the former governor following a petition by members of the Delta State Elders, Leaders and Stakeholders Forum, which was made available to the public in March 2010.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://234next.com/csp/cms/sites/Next/News/National/5540578-146/ibori_faces_new_investigation__.csp |accessdate=March 16, 2010 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20100322220749/http://234next.com/csp/cms/sites/Next/News/National/5540578-146/ibori_faces_new_investigation__.csp |archivedate=March 22, 2010 }}</ref>
===Second set of Nigerian charges=== In April 2010, about three months after the take over of government by [[Goodluck Jonathan]], Ibori's case file was reopened. A new allegation that he embezzled N40 billion ($266 million) was pressed against him. Attempts to arrest him were unsuccessful. It was reported that he fled from [[Abuja]] to [[Lagos]] and then to the creeks of [[Oghara]], his homeland in the [[Niger Delta]]. It was reported that he has been guarded by armed militias and they once had a shoot out with government security forces. He claimed that the charges were frivolous and that he was a victim of political persecution.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://thenationonlineng.net/web2/articles/43966/1/Security-forces-set-for-showdown-with-Ibori/Page1.html |accessdate=April 26, 2010 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20100425183416/http://thenationonlineng.net/web2/articles/43966/1/Security-forces-set-for-showdown-with-Ibori/Page1.html |archivedate=April 25, 2010 }}</ref><ref>{{cite news| url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/1/hi/world/africa/8634835.stm | work=BBC News | title=Nigeria attack halts Ibori arrest | date=21 April 2010}}</ref>
In April 2010, Ibori fled Nigeria, prompting the EFCC to request the assistance of [[Interpol]].<ref>https://archive.is/20111002094443/http://www.punchontheweb.com/Articl.aspx?theartic=Art201004265464445</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.tribune.com.ng/sat/index.php/front-page-articles/931-ibori-still-in-nigeria-intelligence-report.html |accessdate=April 30, 2010 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20100503000244/http://www.tribune.com.ng/sat/index.php/front-page-articles/931-ibori-still-in-nigeria-intelligence-report.html |archivedate=May 3, 2010 }}</ref> On 12 July 2010 the Governor of the CBN, Malam Sanusi Lamido revealed that Ibori had used Delta State as collateral for N40 billion loan when he was governor.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.compassnewspaper.com/NG/index.php?option=com_content&view=article&id=63067:ibori-uses-delta-state-as-collateral-for-n40-billion-loan-says-cbn-governor-&catid=672:top-stories&Itemid=794 |accessdate=July 12, 2010 }}{{dead link|date=May 2016|bot=medic}}{{cbignore|bot=medic}}</ref>
===Arrest in Dubai, extradition to UK=== On 13 May 2010, Ibori was arrested in [[Dubai]], [[United Arab Emirates]] under Interpol arrest warrants, issued from United Kingdom courts and enacted by the [[Metropolitan Police]].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.punchontheweb.com/Articl.aspx?theartic=Art2010051311295937|archiveurl=https://archive.today/20100522091632/http://www.punchontheweb.com/Articl.aspx?theartic=Art2010051311295937|deadurl=yes|title=The Punch:: Ibori arrested in Dubai- Report|date=22 May 2010|archivedate=22 May 2010|website=archive.is}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.huhuonline.com/index.php?option=com_content&view=article&id=1572:chief-james-onanefe-ibori-arrested-in-uaedubai&catid=103:more-news |title=FCT New Transport Policy: Mr. President, Can You Please Fire Bala Mohammed? |publisher=huhuonline |date= |accessdate=2015-07-29}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|author= |url=http://www.vanguardngr.com/2010/05/13/ibori-arraigned-in-dubai-2/ |title=Ibori arraigned in Dubai - Vanguard News |publisher=Vanguardngr.com |date=2010-05-13 |accessdate=2015-07-29}}</ref> Ibori was granted bail pending an extradition hearing.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.saharareporters.com/real-news/sr-headlines/6067-uk-police-confirms-iboris-arrest-in-dubai.html |accessdate=May 13, 2010 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20100515054050/http://www.saharareporters.com/real-news/sr-headlines/6067-uk-police-confirms-iboris-arrest-in-dubai.html |archivedate=May 15, 2010 }}</ref><ref>https://archive.is/20111002095021/http://www.punchontheweb.com/Articl.aspx?theartic=Art20100514630756</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.saharareporters.com/real-news/sr-headlines/6069-ibori-granted-bail-plans-escape-from-dubai.html |accessdate=May 13, 2010 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20100515054131/http://www.saharareporters.com/real-news/sr-headlines/6069-ibori-granted-bail-plans-escape-from-dubai.html |archivedate=May 15, 2010 }}</ref> A spokesman for the Metropolitan Police confirmed that the United Kingdom would "seek Mr Ibori's extradition".<ref>{{cite news| url=https://www.telegraph.co.uk/news/worldnews/africaandindianocean/nigeria/7720634/Nigerian-politician-faces-extradition-to-Britain-on-money-laundering-charges.html | location=London | work=The Daily Telegraph | first=Damien | last=McElroy | title=Nigerian politician faces extradition to Britain on money laundering charges | date=14 May 2010}}</ref>
The Nigerian government and the United Kingdom then agreed to work together on Ibori's extradition to the United Kingdom.<ref>{{cite web|author= |url=http://www.vanguardngr.com/2010/05/14/nigeria-uk-commence-ibori%E2%80%99s-extradition-to-uk/ |title=Nigeria, UK commence Ibori’s extradition to UK - Vanguard News |publisher=Vanguardngr.com |date=2010-05-14 |accessdate=2015-07-29}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://thenationonlineng.net/web2/articles/46531/1/Ibori-has-questions-to-answer-over-35m-assets--Met-police/Page1.html |accessdate=May 14, 2010 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20100517092852/http://thenationonlineng.net/web2/articles/46531/1/Ibori-has-questions-to-answer-over-35m-assets--Met-police/Page1.html |archivedate=May 17, 2010 }}</ref> even as his movement became restricted by the Dubai authority.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.tribune.com.ng/sun/index.php/front-page-articles/1032-iboris-movement-restricted-in-dubai-extradition-case-begins-monday |accessdate=May 16, 2010 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20100520023436/http://www.tribune.com.ng/sun/index.php/front-page-articles/1032-iboris-movement-restricted-in-dubai-extradition-case-begins-monday |archivedate=May 20, 2010 }}</ref> Punch Newspaper however reported on 27 May 2010, that Ibori was seeking political asylum in Dubai.<ref>https://archive.is/20100528163846/http://www.punchontheweb.com/Articl.aspx?theartic=Art201005272304760 </ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.compassnewspaper.com/NG/index.php?option=com_content&view=article&id=52520:uae-offers-to-try-ibori&catid=672:top-stories&Itemid=794 |accessdate=June 5, 2010 }}{{dead link|date=May 2016|bot=medic}}{{cbignore|bot=medic}}</ref>
Ibori's case and extradition became one of the longest, most complex and expensive operations mounted by [[Scotland Yard]] in recent years. Prosecutors alleged that companies owned by Ibori and his family were beneficiaries from the sale of state assets, including shares in a mobile telephone operator, as well as crude oil deliveries.<ref>{{cite web|last=McElroy |first=Damien |url=https://www.telegraph.co.uk/news/worldnews/africaandindianocean/nigeria/7720634/Nigerian-politician-faces-extradition-to-Britain-on-money-laundering-charges.html |title=Nigerian politician faces extradition to Britain on money laundering charges |publisher=Telegraph |date=2010-05-14 |accessdate=2015-07-29}}</ref> The EFCC confirmed on Thursday June 10, 2010, that Ibori was in custody awaiting extradition to the UK.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://234next.com/csp/cms/sites/Next/News/National/5579242-146/dubai_revokes_iboris_bail__.csp |accessdate=June 11, 2010 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20100614182527/http://234next.com/csp/cms/sites/Next/News/National/5579242-146/dubai_revokes_iboris_bail__.csp |archivedate=June 14, 2010 }}</ref>
===Conviction of Associates=== In London, where Ibori is being sought in the case of money laundering, the authority continued with the prosecution of his associates who were in the dock for helping Ibori to launder money.
On 1st and 2 June 2010, UK juries found James Ibori's sister, Christine Ibie-Ibori<ref>{{cite web|url=http://thenationonlineng.net/web2/articles/48541/1/UK-court-convicts-Iboris-sister/Page1.html |accessdate=June 2, 2010 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20100605192242/http://thenationonlineng.net/web2/articles/48541/1/UK-court-convicts-Iboris-sister/Page1.html |archivedate=June 5, 2010 }}</ref> and his associate, Udoamaka Okoronkwo, guilty on counts of money laundering, in a verdict delivered at the Southwark Crown Court, London.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://234next.com/csp/cms/sites/Next/News/Metro/Crime/5575623-146/uk_court_declares_iboris_associate_guilty.csp |accessdate=June 2, 2010 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20100605180425/http://234next.com/csp/cms/sites/Next/News/Metro/Crime/5575623-146/uk_court_declares_iboris_associate_guilty.csp |archivedate=June 5, 2010 }}</ref> Mr. James Ibori, via his media aide released a statement questioning the validity of the verdict which he claimed absolved the two other women, Ms Okoronkwo and Adebimpe Pogoson who were charged alongside his sister.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.tribune.com.ng/index.php/front-page-news/6274-london-court-convicts-iboris-sister-ex-delta-gov-rejects-verdict |accessdate=June 2, 2010 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20100605055449/http://www.tribune.com.ng/index.php/front-page-news/6274-london-court-convicts-iboris-sister-ex-delta-gov-rejects-verdict |archivedate=June 5, 2010 }}</ref> The jury's verdict of 2 June 2010 however returned a guilty decision against Okoronkwo as well.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.punchontheweb.com/Articl.aspx?theartic=Art2010060213531471|archiveurl=https://archive.today/20111002095403/http://www.punchontheweb.com/Articl.aspx?theartic=Art2010060213531471|deadurl=yes|title=The Punch:: UK Court indicts another Ibori‘s associate|date=2 October 2011|archivedate=2 October 2011|website=archive.is}}</ref> Christine Ibie-Ibori and Udoamaka Okoronkwo were each sentenced to 5 years in prison on Monday 7 June 2010 by the UK court even as the defense counsel pleaded for mercy that the convicts were merely manipulated by James Ibori.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.saharareporters.com/news/6223-iboris-associates-sentenced-to-21-years-in-prison.html |accessdate=June 7, 2010 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20100609133131/http://www.saharareporters.com/news/6223-iboris-associates-sentenced-to-21-years-in-prison.html |archivedate=June 9, 2010 }}</ref>
===Conviction=== On 27 February 2012, accused of stealing US$250 million from the Nigerian public purse, Ibori pleaded guilty to ten counts of money laundering and conspiracy to defraud at [[Southwark Crown Court]], [[London]].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://customwire.ap.org/dynamic/stories/E/EU_BRITAIN_NIGERIA_IBORI?SITE=NDBIS&SECTION=HOME&TEMPLATE=DEFAULT&CTIME=2012-02-27-14-47-07 |accessdate=March 2, 2012 }}{{dead link|date=May 2016|bot=medic}}{{cbignore|bot=medic}}</ref>
Following the guilty plea entered by Ibori, the EFCC brought before an Appeal Court the 6 year old ruling of a Federal High Court in Asaba which acquitted Ibori in 2009.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://allafrica.com/stories/201203010327.html | title=Nigeria: EFCC Awaits Appeal Court Date On Ibori's 170 Count Charges| author=RONALD MUTUM| publisher=All Africa| date=29 February 2012}}</ref> They EFCC sought the court to set aside the ruling of the lower court on the grounds that the presiding judge, Justice Awokulehin, erred in law while delivering his judgement. A three-man panel of justices at the Benin Division of the Court of Appeal on May 15, 2014 ruled that the ex- governor has a case to answer. With this judgment, the coast is clear for Ibori to face further trial in Nigeria upon the completion of his jail term in London.
On Tuesday, April 17, 2012, Ibori was sentenced to 13 years by Southwark Crown Court for his crimes.<ref name=BBC17739388>{{cite news| url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/world-africa-17739388 | work=BBC News | title=Former Nigeria governor James Ibori jailed for 13 years | date=17 April 2012}}</ref><ref>[http://dailytimes.com.ng/article/ibori-gets-13-year Ibori gets 13 years] {{webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20120420020024/http://dailytimes.com.ng/article/ibori-gets-13-years |date=April 20, 2012 }}</ref> Among possessions confiscated were:<ref name=BBC17739388/> *A house in [[Hampstead]], north London, for £2.2m * A property in [[Shaftesbury]], [[Dorset]], for £311,000 * A £3.2m mansion in Sandton, near [[Johannesburg]], [[South Africa]] * A fleet of armoured [[Range Rover (L322)|Range Rovers]] valued at £600,000 * A £120,000 [[Bentley Continental GT]] * A [[Mercedes-Benz]] [[Maybach 57 and 62|Maybach 62]] bought for €407,000 cash, that was shipped direct to his mansion in South Africa
After the sentencing hearing, Sue Patten, head of the [[Crown Prosecution Service]] central fraud group, said it would bid to confiscate the assets Ibori had acquired his riches "at the expense of some of the poorest people in the world".<ref name=BBC17739388/>
==Release== James Ibori was released from prison in December 2016 after a court order. He served 4 years out of the 13 years he was sentenced to.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.premiumtimesng.com/news/top-news/218612-james-ibori-released-london-prison-reports.html|title=James Ibori released from London Prison - Reports - Premium Times Nigeria|date=21 December 2016|publisher=}}</ref>
There is indication of his arraignment in Nigeria courts as it is believed that his conviction in United Kingdom is not related to several other financial improprieties committed by him.

The '''Kasgar''' are a [[Muslim]] community, found in the state of [[Uttar Pradesh]] in [[India]] .<ref>People of India Uttar Pradesh Volume XLII Part Two edited by A Hasan & J C Das pages 747 to 750</ref> After independence of [[Pakistan]] in 1947, many Kasgar migrated and resettled in [[Pakistan]]. They are now found mainly in [[Sindh]] province and have become part of [[Muhajir (Pakistan)|Muhajir]] community.
==History and present circumstances==
The Kasgar (from [[Persian language|Persian]] کاسگر meaning goblet-makers) are an occupational group who are makers of the '' kas kuza (Persian: کاسه کوزه)'' goblets and other earthen pots. They are concentrated in the [[Awadh]] region of [[Uttar Pradesh]]. Information regarding the origin of the community is obscure. They are similar to Muslim kumhar in west uttar pradesh. The Kasgar are an endogamous community, and they practice both parallel and cross cousin marriages.
Among the Kasgar, the caste council known as a [[panchayat]], plays an important role in resolving disputes among the community. They perceive themselves to be of [[Shaikhs in South Asia|Shaikh]] status. The community is split by sectarian affiliation, with some members belonging to the [[Shia]] sects, while others are [[Sunni]].<ref>People of India Uttar Pradesh Volume XLII edited by A Hasan & J C Das page 746</ref>

'''Kurds in Israel''' refers to people of [[Kurdish people|Kurdish]] origin residing in [[Israel]]. The Kurdish population in Israel is small and is mainly composed of individuals and families, who fled Iraq and Turkey during the [[Iraqi–Kurdish conflict|Iraqi–Kurdish]] and the [[Kurdish–Turkish conflict]]s<ref>{{lang-he|טורקיה והכורדים: קלאב MAD}} [http://news.walla.co.il/item/967428]</ref> during the 20th century, as well as temporal residents arriving in Israel for medical care.
==Population== Historically, a small Arabized population of Kurdish origins exists in Galilee and Jerusalem area, though it has mostly intermixed with local Arabs; their exact numbers are not available since they are counted as ethnic Arabs in the official Israeli census. Some Arabized families of Kurdish background can still be identified by specific surnames.
The Kurdish population in Israel is small and is mainly composed of individuals and families, who fled Iraq and Turkey during the [[Iraqi–Kurdish conflict|Iraqi–Kurdish]] and the [[Kurdish–Turkish conflict]]s during the 20th century. In 2006, the number of Kurdish refugees from Turkey was estimated at 200.<ref>{{lang-he|טורקיה והכורדים: קלאב MAD}} [http://news.walla.co.il/item/967428]</ref> Another estimate for both Iraqi and Turkish Kurds was 150 persons in 2007.
In March 2001, a group of 19 Kurdish men entered Israel via Lebanon, asking for asylum, but were denied.<ref>[http://www.tau.ac.il/law/clinics/english/Safe%20heaven.pdf]</ref> In mid-2001, a group of 42 [[Kurdish refugees]] attempted to enter Israel via Lebanon, illegally crossing the Israeli–Lebanese border, but were returned to Lebanon.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.haaretz.co.il/misc/1.725117|title=נדחתה בקשתם של 42 כורדים למקלט מדיני|date=10 August 2001|work=Haaretz}}</ref>
In 2007, 40 Iraqi Kurdish children, mostly from [[Iraqi Kurdistan]], were hosted with their parents and medically treated in Israel, as part of the project initiated by Israeli ''Save a Child’s Heart Organization'' (SACH).<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.ima.org.il/eng|title=IMA -|first=Slavin-Internet|last=Technologies|publisher=}}</ref> In 2013, it was reported that Israel accepted three Kurdish children from Iraqi Kurdistan for medical treatment.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://ekurd.net/mismas/articles/misc2013/12/state7616.htm|title=Kurdish children from Iraqi Kurdistan receive medical treatment in Israel|publisher=}}</ref> The children were settled into Wolfson Medical Center in Holon, southern Tel Aviv area. They were some of the 183 children with Iraqi nationality, entering Israel for medical treatment since the establishment of the program.
In January 2015, Yazidi organizations made an official request from Israeli government to absorb Yazidi refugees from Iraq. There was no official statement by Israeli government as a result, but Yazidi sources claimed that refugee absorption took place and thanked Israeli government.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.news1.co.il/Archive/001-D-379131-00.html|title=News1 - האם ייתכן שישראל קלטה פליטים יזידים|publisher=}}</ref> There was no response from Israeli Parliament members, upon asking them on this matter of absorbing Yazidi refugees.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.timesofisrael.com/israels-yazidi-ambassador-explains-why-so-many-want-to-join-the-idf/|title=Israel’s Yazidi ‘ambassador’ explains why so many want to join the IDF |work=Times of Israel}}</ref>
==Relations with Israeli Jewish community of Kurdistani background== Israel is a home to some 200,000 Jews of [[History of the Jews in Kurdistan|Kurdistani]] origins, who are mostly descended from nearly 50 thousand Kurdish Jews evacuated from Iraq during [[Operation Ezra and Nehemiah]] in the early 1950s. [[Israeli Jews]] of Kurdistani background preserve ties with the ethnic Kurdish communities in the Middle East, including with the Kurdish individuals residing in Israel.

{{Romani people}} '''Lovari''' ("horse-dealer", from Hungarian "ló", ''horse'') is a subgroup of the [[Romani people]], who speak their own dialect, influenced by [[Hungarian language|Hungarian]] and [[West Slavic languages|West Slavic]] dialects. They live predominantly throughout [[Central Europe]] ([[Hungary]], [[Poland]], [[Slovakia]], the [[Czech Republic]], and [[Germany]]) as well as in [[Romania]], [[Croatia]], [[France]], [[Italy]], [[Greece]] and [[Ukraine]].
==Ethnology== The ''Lovari'' are a [[Romani people]] who speak a dialect influenced by [[Hungarian language|Hungarian]] and [[West Slavic languages|West Slavic]] dialects. The Lovari are further divided into the '''Machvaya''', named after the [[Mačva]] region, which they settled from modern day Hungary.
==Employment== Their historical trade was horse-trading and fortune-telling.
==Customs== Lovari's traditional costume is based on traditional Central European Romani national costumes and is seldom used nowadays. They also have very strict contamination customs.
==Diaspora== [[Tucson, Arizona]] and [[Hamilton, Ontario]] both house large numbers of Machvaya as do the United States, Canada, [[Brazil]] and the United Kingdom as a whole.

{{Infobox ethnic group |group = Ngalop |image = |caption = |population = 708,500 |popplace = Western, Northern and parts of South-East and South [[Bhutan]] ([[Thimphu District|Thimphu]], [[Gasa District|Gasa]], [[Punakha District|Punakha]], [[Wangdue Phodrang District|Wangdue Phodrang]], [[Haa District|Haa]], [[Paro District|Paro]], [[Chukha District|Chukha]]) |langs = [[Dzongkha]] |rels = [[Buddhism]]{{·}}[[Bon]] |related-c = [[Tibetan people|Tibetan]]{{·}}[[Monpa people|Monpa]]{{·}}[[Sharchops|Sharchop]]{{·}}Other [[Sino-Tibetan languages|Sino-Tibetan-speaking peoples]], [[Assamese people|Indigenous Assamese people]] }} The '''Ngalop''' ({{lang-dz|སྔལོངཔ་}} {{bo|w=snga long pa}}; "earliest risen people" or "first converted people" according to [[folk etymology]])<ref name=vanDriem93>{{cite web|url=http://repository.forcedmigration.org/pdf/?pid=fmo:3003 |format=PDF |last=van Driem |first=George L. |authorlink=George van Driem |title=Language Policy in Bhutan |publisher=[[School of Oriental and African Studies|SOAS]] |location=[[London]] |year=1993 |accessdate=2011-01-18}}</ref> are people of [[Tibet]]an origin who migrated to [[Bhutan]] as early as the ninth century. Orientalists adopted the term "Bhote" or [[Bhotiya]], meaning "people of Bod ([[Tibet]])", a term also applied to the [[Tibetan people]], leading to confusion, and now is rarely used in reference to the Ngalop.
The Ngalop introduced [[Tibetan culture]] and [[Buddhism]] to Bhutan and comprise the dominant political and cultural element in modern Bhutan. Furthermore, cultural, ethnic, and linguistic identity in Bhutan are not always mutually exclusive. For these reasons, Ngalops are often simply identified as '''Bhutanese'''. Their language, [[Dzongkha]], is the national language and is descended from Old Tibetan. The Ngalop are dominant in western and northern Bhutan, including [[Thimphu]] and the Dzongkha-speaking region. The term Ngalop may subsume several related linguistic and cultural groups, such as the [[Kheng people]] and speakers of [[Bumthang language]].<ref name=vanDriem93/><ref name=CS-EG>{{Country study|author=Robert L. Worden |country=Bhutan |abbr=bt |section=Ethnic Groups |editor=Andrea Matles Savada |date = September 1991|pd=yes}}</ref><ref name=CS-I>{{Country study|author=Robert L. Worden |country=Bhutan |abbr=bt |section=Introduction |editor=Andrea Matles Savada |date = September 1991|pd=yes}}</ref>
==Population== The Ngalop are concentrated in the western and central valleys of Bhutan, whose total population in 2010 was about 708,500.<ref name=CIA/> Together the Ngalop, [[Sharchops]] and tribal groups constituted up to 72 percent of the population in the late 1980s according to official Bhutanese statistics.<ref name=CS-EG/><ref name=CS-s>{{Country study|author=Robert L. Worden |country=Bhutan |abbr=bt |section=Society |editor=Andrea Matles Savada |date = September 1991|pd=yes}}</ref> The 1981 census claimed Sharchops represented 30% of the population and Ngalops about 17%.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.satp.org/satporgtp/countries/bhutan/backgrounders/index.html |title=Bhutan Backgrounder |work=SATP online |publisher=South Asia Terrorism Portal |date=2002-09-20 |accessdate=2011-07-10}}</ref> ''[[The World Factbook]]'', however, estimates the "Bhote" Ngalop and Sharchop populations together to total about 50 percent, or 354,200.<ref name=CIA>{{CIA_World_Factbook_link|bt|Bhutan}}</ref> Assuming Sharchops still outnumber Ngalops some three to two, the total Ngalop population is around 141,700.
==Language== Ngalops speak [[Dzongkha]]. As Ngalops are politically and culturally dominant in Bhutan, Dzongkha is the language of government and education throughout the kingdom. Other groups that identify as culturally Ngalop speak the [[Kheng language|Kheng]] and [[Bumthang language]]s. To a large extent, even the [[Sharchops]] of eastern Bhutan, who speak [[Tshangla language|Tshangla]], have adopted Ngalop culture and may identify as Ngalop.<ref name=vanDriem93/><ref name=CS-EG/><ref name="CS-EG"/><ref name=CS-L>{{Country study|author=Robert L. Worden |country=Bhutan |abbr=bt |section=Languages |editor=Andrea Matles Savada |date = September 1991|pd=yes}}</ref>
==Religion== Ngalops largely follow [[Tibetan Buddhism]], particularly the [[Drukpa Lineage]] of the [[Kagyu]] school of [[Vajrayana]] that is the [[state religion]] of Bhutan. A significant number also follow the [[Nyingma]] school, which was dominant in early [[history of Bhutan|Bhutanese history]].
===Bon=== {{main|Bon in Bhutan}} [[Bon]] practitioners are a minority, although the practices of the Ngalops, like that of most Bhutanese, are characterized by incorporated elements of the older [[ethnic religion]] that is also referred to by the term ''Bon''.<ref name=CS-EG/><ref name=CS-RT>{{Country study|author=Robert L. Worden |country=Bhutan |abbr=bt |section=Religious Tradition |editor=Andrea Matles Savada |date = September 1991|pd=yes}}</ref>
==Lifestyle== The primary agricultural crops are [[Bhutanese red rice]], [[potato]]es, [[barley]], and other temperate climate crops. Ngalop people build houses out of timber, stone, clay, and brick. The Ngalop are also known for building large fortress-monasteries known as [[dzong architecture|dzong]]s that now serve as government offices. The [[Druk Gyalpo]] and most of the government are Ngalop, and all citizens of the country are required to follow the national dress code, the [[driglam namzha]], which is Ngalop in origin.<ref name=CS-EG/><ref name=CS-H>{{Country study|author=Robert L. Worden |country=Bhutan |abbr=bt |section=Housing |editor=Andrea Matles Savada |date = September 1991|pd=yes}}</ref>
The Ngalops follow [[matrilineal]] lines in the inheritance of land and livestock.<ref>{{cite web|title=Women in Agriculture, Environment and Rural Production|url=ftp://ftp.fao.org/Gender/BHU.PDF|website=Fact Sheet Bhutan|publisher=Food and Agriculture Organization of the United Nations|accessdate=8 Sep 2017}}</ref>
==See also== * [[Ethnic groups in Bhutan]]
